text: <header>Catalyst preparation<text>The hierarchical ZSM-5 was prepared through the post-treatment method using NaZSM-5 as parent zeolite (Si/Al = 13.5, Catalyst Plant of Nankai University). For the alkaline treatment, 3.33 g of NaZSM-5 zeolites were added into 100 ml NaOH solution (0.1, 0.2, and 0.4 M) under stirring of 600 rpm and heated at 338 K for 0.5 h. After that, the mixture was quenched by adding distilled water, followed by filtration, washing to neutral with extensive distilled water, and drying at 333 K for 12 h. The zeolites obtained by alkaline treatment are expressed by NaZSM-5-OHx, where x is the concentration of NaOH. For the acid treatment, 1 g alkali-treated zeolite (or NaZSM-5 zeolite) was loaded into 100 ml 0.1 M HCl solution under stirring of 600 rpm and heated at 338 K for 6 h. Then, the resulting suspension was quenched, followed by filtration, washing, and drying in the same procedure as the alkaline treatment. The zeolites obtained by acid treatment are denoted by NaZSM-5-OHx-H (or NaZSM-5-H). All zeolites were ion-exchanged with 1 M NH4Cl solution at 353 K for 3 h, which was continuously carried out three times. Subsequently, the mixture was filtered, washed until no Cl- was detected (by adding AgNO3), and calcined at 823 K for 5 h in static air. Zeolite notations and modification conditions are summarized in Table S1. Cobalt-type (Co-type) zeolites were prepared to investigate the specific location of Al in the zeolite framework. Briefly, sodium-type (Na-type) zeolites were subjected to ion exchange in 0.05 M Co(NO3)2·6H2O solution at 353 K for 12 h. The ion-exchange process was repeated three times to ensure that the cobalt cations were in a (super)saturated state. The Co-type zeolites were dried overnight in an oven at 333 K, followed by calcination at 773 K for 5 h under nitrogen atmosphere to dehydrate Co(H2O)6 2+ toward bare Co2+.

<header>Catalyst preparation<text>Commercial NH4 +-ZSM-5 (Si/Al2 = 23, Alfa Aesar) was purchased and converted to H-ZSM-5 (denoted as Z afterward) by calcination at 550 C for 5 h, using a ramping rate of 5 C/min. Active metal species were introduced to Z via wetness impregnation. Ammonium molybdate tetrahydrate (NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O (Sigma Aldrich), zinc nitrate hexahydrate Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (Alfa Aesar), and gallium nitrate hydrate Ga(NO3)3·xH2O (Sigma Aldrich) were used as Mo, Zn, and Ga precursors, respectively. Predetermined amounts of Z were added to aqueous solutions of each metal precursor with various nominal metal loadings and rigorously stirred for 1 h. Water was removed from the solutions using a rotary evaporator (Buchi, Rotavapor R-300), and the remaining products were dried overnight in a 105 C heating oven. The samples were calcined at specific temperatures for 5 h depending on the introduced metal species (500 C for Mo and 550 C for Zn, Ga), using a ramping rate of 5 C/min. The obtained catalysts were nominated with respect to the loading of the active metal (e.g., 2Mo/Z represents the sample with 2 wt% Mo impregnated on Z). Note that this nomination does not indicate that the active metals were in their metallic form; rather, Mo, Zn, and Ga were present in their oxidized state following calcination.

Soybean oil was bought from a local store in the Eastern Province of Saudi Arabia. All the reagents used were of analytical grade; Sigma-Aldrich supplied all of the chemicals (St. Louis, MO, USA): methanol (purity >99%), sodium hydroxide (NaOH), n-heptane (99% pure), zirconium (IV) oxynitrate hydrate, ammonium nitrate (NH4NO3). The commercial zeolite, NH4-ZSM-5 was purchased from Zeolyst International. <header>Catalyst preparation<text>The NH4-ZSM-5 zeolite was calcined at 550 C under a steady flow of air for 6 h to convert it to H-ZSM-5 as a catalyst support for the production of biodiesel. The modification of H-ZSM-5 zeolite was carried out by desilication (following zeolite synthesis, silicon is extracted from the framework using alkaline treatment) at 80 C for 4 h with a series of NaOH concentrations (0.1–0.3 M) under atmospheric pressure. In a reflux condenser-equipped flask, a 30-milliliter solution of NaOH was heated to 80 C, then pre-determined amount of H-ZSM-5 zeolite (550 C calcined) was added and agitated for 4 h at 600 rpm. After desilication with an alkaline solution, deionized water was used to wash the suspension before it was filtered, dried for 8 h at 120 C and Na+/NH4+ ion exchange was then performed using 1 M NH4NO3 at 120 C for 4 h (ion exchange was carried out twice, one after the other with 1 M NH4NO3). The mixture was then cooled before being centrifuged at 780 rpm. The precipitate generated was purified by washing it three times with distilled water to get rid of any impurities. After drying for 10 h at 120 C, the reaction mixture was calcined in a muffle furnace for a total of 6 h at 550 C. The resulting desilicated zeolite sample was denoted as ZSM-5(concentration), where concentration denotes the concentration of the NaOH used in the alkaline treatment. The wet impregnation approach was used to prepare the ZrO2/ZSM-5 catalyst. The catalyst was prepared by slowly adding pre-determined amount of zirconium (IV) oxynitrate hydrate as a precursor for zirconia, and an appropriate amount of ZSM-5 to 12 ml of distilled water and agitating it at 60 C for 3 h. The precipitate that formed was dried for 11 h at a temperature of 120 C. Finally, the synthesized catalyst was calcined for 6 h at 550 C and was denoted as ZrO2/ZSM-5. The ZrO2/ZSM-5(NaOH solution concentration) catalyst was also synthesized by a similar approach utilizing desilicated zeolite ZSM-5(NaOH solution concentration) as a support.

NaX zeolite with a framework Si/Al ratio of 1.17 (unit cell composition: Na88.48Al88.48Si103.52O384) was supplied by Nankai University Catalyst Co., Ltd. Rare-earth salts, including lanthanum nitrate hexahydrate (≥ 99.5%), praseodymium (III) nitrate hexahydrate (≥ 99.5%), neodymium nitrate hexahydrate (≥ 99.5%), and samarium(III) nitrate hexahydrate (≥ 99.5%) were purchased from Shanghai Macklin Biochemical Co., Ltd. Liquified isobutane (≥ 99.9%) and 2-butene (≥ 99.9%) were obtained from Dalian Airichem Specialty Gases & Chemicals Co., Ltd. <header>Catalyst preparation<text>The incorporation of rare-earth cations into X zeolite was achieved through a double-exchange, double-calcination approach. A typical procedure was conducted as follows: NaX zeolite was exchanged with 0.2 mol/L rare earth nitrate solution with a liquid-to-solid ratio of 20 mL g-1. The ion exchange process was conducted at 80 C for 2 h and repeated once. After filtration, washing, and drying at 120 C overnight, the resulting sample was calcined in air atmosphere with a heating rate of 0.5 C min-1 up to 450 C. After fully rehydrated, the procedure above was subsequently replicated to attain a significant level of ion exchange.

<header>Microwave (MW)-assisted chelation-alkaline treatment of ZSM-5<text>The parent ZSM-5 was calcined at 550 C for 5 h to convert it to an H-form counterpart before the treatment. The MW-assisted chelation-alkaline treatment was carried out in a mono-mode microwave reactor (Anton Paar, Monowave 300). Specifically, in a typical treatment, in a 30 mL quartz vessel, 1 g calcined parent ZSM-5 zeolite was dispersed in 20 mL chelation-alkaline medium with 0.2 M NaOH and x M Na2H2EDTA, (where x was 0, i.e., the conventional alkaline treatment without EDTA, 0.1, 0.3 and 0.5 M). Then, the vessel was sealed by a rubber cap and introduced into the MW reactor, heated to 65 C as quick as possible and maintained for y min (y = 3 and 30 min) under stirring at 800 rpm. Relevant samples from the post-treatment in this work are denoted as Z-MW-x-y accordingly. After the treatment, the vessel was taken out from the MW reactor immediately and cooled in an ice-water bath. Then, the resulting mixture was centrifuged (at 4400 rpm for 7 min) to separate the solid sample (from the mixture) which was washed using deionized water 4 times and dried in an oven at 100 C for 12 h. As shown in Fig. 1 a, a control sample was prepared as well by the conventional heating (using a water bath) under the hydrothermal condition at 65 C using the mixed solution with 0.3 M Na2H2EDTA and 0.2 NaOH aqueous solution for 30 min, and the resulting control sample was denoted as Z-HT-0.3–30. All the obtained ZSM-5 zeolites were ion-exchanged for catalysis. In detail, the as-prepared zeolite (1 g) was dispersed in 40 mL of 1 M NH4NO3 solution (1 M) in a flask. The mixture was heated by a water bath at 80 C for 12 h under stirring (at 500 rpm), then the solid was separated by centrifugation (at 4400 rpm for 7 min) and washed with deionized water four times. Ion exchange was repeated twice under the same condition, and then the zeolite samples were dried in an oven at 100 C for 12 h. Before catalysis, all the ion-exchanged zeolites were calcined in a muffle oven at 550 C for 5 h with a ramp rate of 5 C/min.

<header>Materials and catalyst preparation<text>Synthesis of hierarchical HZSM-5 catalysts . The pristine HZSM-5 (SiO2/Al2O3 = 85) catalyst was purchased from Nankai University Catalyst Plant (Tianjin, China), and it was denoted as H-Z5-1. Hierarchical ZSM-5 catalysts were synthesized as explained below. First, the parent HZSM-5 was calcined in flowing air at 550 C for 4 h. Then, the calcined samples were treated with an alkaline solution with varying TPA+ concentrations of TPA+/OH- = 0, 0.25, 0.5, 0.75, and 1 for 1 h at 70 C. The concentration of OH- (C OH -) was maintained at 0.2 M, and the solution amount was kept at 30 mL g-1 parent HZSM-5 for alkaline treatment. These samples were denoted as H-Z5-2, H-Z5-3, H-Z5-4, H-Z5-5, and H-Z5-6, respectively. After alkaline treatment, the suspension was cooled down in an ice bath, centrifugated, and washed with deionized water until the pH = 7. The obtained powder was dried at 80 C for 12 h and calcined at 550 C for 4 h. The collected powder was then ion-exchanged three times with 0.5 M NH4NO3 at 80 C for 1 h. Finally, the resulting samples were centrifugated, washed, dried, and calcined as described above to obtain the hierarchical HZSM-5 catalysts. The obtained catalysts are shown in the following table - <R><C>Sample<C>Base<C>[ITALICS] C TPA+/OH-<C>[ITALICS] C OH-<C>[ITALICS] C AHFS<C>[ITALICS] T ( C)<C>t (h)<R><C>H-Z5-1<C>–<C>–<C>–<C>–<C>–<C>–<R><C>H-Z5-2<C>NaOH<C>0<C>0.2<C>–<C>70<C>1<R><C>H-Z5-3<C>TPAOH&NaOH<C>0.25<C>0.2<C>–<C>70<C>1<R><C>H-Z5-4<C>TPAOH&NaOH<C>0.5<C>0.2<C>–<C>70<C>1<R><C>H-Z5-5<C>TPAOH&NaOH<C>0.75<C>0.2<C>–<C>70<C>1<R><C>H-Z5-6<C>TPAOH<C>1<C>0.2<C>–<C>70<C>1<R><C>AHFS0.01<C>AHFS<C>–<C>–<C>0.01<C>80<C>1<R><C>AHFS0.1<C>AHFS<C>–<C>–<C>0.1<C>80<C>1<R><C>AHFS0.1<C>AHFS<C>–<C>–<C>0.1<C>80<C>1<Cap>The synthesis of HZSM-5 catalysts.</Cap> . AHFS-treated HZSM-5 catalyst . AHFS treatment was performed on the H-Z5-1 and H-Z5-4 catalysts. 4 g of H-Z5-1 was treated with AHFS solutions (30 mL) of 0.01 and 0.1 M for 1 h at 80 C, and they were denoted as AHFS0.01-Z5-1 and AHFS0.1-Z5-1, respectively. In the same way, AHFS0.1-Z5-4 was obtained from treatment of H-Z5-4 treated using a 0.1 M AHFS solution. Then, the obtained products were centrifuged, washed, dried, and calcined according to the same procedure for synthesizing hierarchical HZSM-5 catalysts. The obtained catalysts are listed in the following table - <R><C>Sample<C>Base<C>[ITALICS] C TPA+/OH-<C>[ITALICS] C OH-<C>[ITALICS] C AHFS<C>[ITALICS] T ( C)<C>t (h)<R><C>H-Z5-1<C>–<C>–<C>–<C>–<C>–<C>–<R><C>H-Z5-2<C>NaOH<C>0<C>0.2<C>–<C>70<C>1<R><C>H-Z5-3<C>TPAOH&NaOH<C>0.25<C>0.2<C>–<C>70<C>1<R><C>H-Z5-4<C>TPAOH&NaOH<C>0.5<C>0.2<C>–<C>70<C>1<R><C>H-Z5-5<C>TPAOH&NaOH<C>0.75<C>0.2<C>–<C>70<C>1<R><C>H-Z5-6<C>TPAOH<C>1<C>0.2<C>–<C>70<C>1<R><C>AHFS0.01<C>AHFS<C>–<C>–<C>0.01<C>80<C>1<R><C>AHFS0.1<C>AHFS<C>–<C>–<C>0.1<C>80<C>1<R><C>AHFS0.1<C>AHFS<C>–<C>–<C>0.1<C>80<C>1<Cap>The synthesis of HZSM-5 catalysts.</Cap>. Synthesis of silicalite-1 (S1) with pure LAS (LAS-S1) . To synthesize S1 zeolite, 13 g TPAOH solution was added to deionized water under vigorous stirring. Then, 8.32 g tetraethyl orthosilicate was slowly added to the above mixture. When tetraethyl orthosilicate was fully dissolved, the clear reaction mixture was transferred into a 100 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave for crystallization at 170 C for 96 h. The molar composition of the synthesis solution was 0.4 TPAOH: 1.0 SiO2: 35 H2O. The as-synthesized solid products were centrifuged, washed with deionized water and ethanol for three times, and then dried at 80 C for 12 h, followed by calcination at 550 C for 8 h (Wang et al., 2016). LAS-S1 catalyst was synthesized by incipient wetness impregnation of S1 with Al(NO3)3·9H2O for 24 h and the Al loading was 15 wt%. The catalyst was subsequently dried at 80 C under continuous stirring and 105 C for complete dryness. Finally, the dried catalysts were calcined at 550 C for 4 h.

text: <header>Chemicals<text>Tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS, AR), tetrapropylammonium hydroxide solution (TPAOH, 25 wt%), ammonium chloride (NH4Cl, AR), sodium aluminate (NaAlO2, AR), sodium hydroxide (NaOH, AR), pyridine (AR, 99.8 %), commercial ZSM-5 (denoted as NK70) was purchased from Nankai University Catalyst Co. Ltd., which has similar acid content and physical property with hier-ZSM-5 (BZ5(30,50), Part 3.3) (Fu et al., 2021). Commercial raw RH was bought from a farm in Anhui province (China). A certain mass of commercial rice husks was dispersed into deionized water (solid–liquid ratio = 1:50) and uniformly stirred at room temperature using an electric mixer to remove surface-attached impurities. After repeated treatment three times and following drying, the final sample was obtained.<header>Preparation of hier-ZSM-5 with different Na<text>Firstly, NaAlO2 and NaOH were dissolved in water and added to the mixed solution of TEOS and TPAOH, respectively. The molecular composition of the growth liquid was as follows: 60 SiO2: m Al2O3: 44 TPAOH: n Na2O: 11,975 H2O. After stirring the mixture for one minute, 5 g of the cleaned RH was added and stirred for 10 h, then transferred to a Teflon-lined autoclave (volume of 100 mL) for zeolite crystallization at 170 C for 24 h. The Na-type ZSM-5 was filtered with deionized water until the catalyst filtrate was neutral, dried at 100 C, and calcined at 550 C for 6 h. To obtain H-type ZSM-5, the calcined Na-type ZSM-5 was ion-exchanged three times with 1 mol/L NH4Cl aqueous solution at 90 C for 1 h, and the H-hier-ZSM-5 was calcined at 550 C for 6 h. The obtained catalyst was named BZ5(X, Y); the X refers to the SiO2/Al2O3 ratio (20, 30, 50, and 60) of the synthetic solution, while the Y refers to the ratio of Na2O/Al2O3 (0, 25, 50, and 75) in the growth solution.<header>Hier-ZSM-5 prepared by different crystallization manners<text>The above catalysts were all prepared by hydrothermal crystallization in static conditions. To compare the effects of different crystallization manners on the hier-ZSM-5, we set the rotation crystallization. The only difference between rotary crystallization and standing crystallization is that the final crystallization kettle is transferred to a 170 C rotary oven at a rate of 5 r/min for 24 h. The zeolite obtained by rotating was named as RBZ5(30, 50). In contrast, the BZ5(30, 50) represented the zeolite prepared with static crystallization.

text: SL was ground into 16–40 mesh particles as the feedstock and dried at 105 C for 12 h before the experiments. The basic properties of SL can be referenced from prior work (Zhao et al., 2023). Details regarding the catalyst preparation materials are provided in the Supplementary Information. <header>Catalyst preparation<text>The catalysts was synthesized according to the previously reported method (Fu et al., 2020). Al(NO3)3, TEOS, and TPAOH were employed as the Al, Si, and template sources, respectively, with a molar ratio of 60 SiO2: 1 Al2O3: 15 TPAOH: 5 Na2O: 500 H2O. The diagram of catalyst preparation is shown in Fig. 1 . Specifically, 36.2 g of TEOS was added to 35.3 g of TPAOH and stirred at 80 C for 2 h to prepare the synthesis gel. Successively, 2.2 g of Al(NO3)3 and 1.2 g of NaOH were dissolved in 25.1 g of deionized water, added dropwise to the gel, and stirred for 5.5 h. The resulting mixture underwent hydrothermal synthesis at 170 C for 24 h in a 100 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. After synthesis, the samples were separated, washed with deionized water, dried at 100 C overnight, and calcinated for 6 h at 550 C to obtain Na-PHZ5 catalysts. The Na-PHZ5 was further modified by mixing TPAOH solutions of various concentrations (0.1–0.7 M) at a solid–liquid ratio of 1:10 for 10 min, followed by heat treated at 170 C for 48 h in a 100 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The resulting product was collected, washed to neutral, and dried at 100 C overnight. The solid product obtained was then calcined in a muffle furnace at 550 C for 6 h. Similar treatment was applied to Na-PHZ5 by adding TPABr (0.1 and 0.2 M) to a 0.3 M TPAOH solution. All catalysts were ion-exchanged with 1 M NH4Cl (20 mL NH4Cl/1 g catalysts) at 80 C for 2 h repeated thrice, followed by drying and calcination at 550 C for 6 h. The resultant parent catalyst was labeled PHZ5, and those further treated with TPAOH (0.1, 0.3, 0.5, and 0.7 M) were denoted HZ5-1T, HZ5-3T, HZ5-5T, and HZ5-7T, respectively. The catalysts co-hydrothermally treated with TPAOH (0.3 M) and TPABr (0.1 and 0.2 M) were named HZ5-3T1B and HZ5-3T2B.

text: In this work, sodium aluminate (NaAlO2, 98 wt%) and SiO2 gel (AS-40, 40 wt%) were used as the aluminum and silicon resources, respectively. Sodium hydroxide (NaOH, 97 wt%) was the alkali source and hexamethonium bromide (HMBr2, 98 wt%) was the structure directing agent (SDA). Dimethyloctadecyl[3-(trimethoxysilyl)propyl]ammonium chloride solution (C26H58ClNO3Si, 40 wt% in methanol, containing (3-chloropropyl)trimethoxysilane) was used as the organosilane reagent, labeled as TPOAC. Potassium bromide (KBr, 99 %) was used for FT-IR test. SiO2 gel was purchased from Shanghai Sigma-Aldrich Trading Co. Ltd. Sodium aluminate was supplied by Shanghai Macklin Biochemical Co. Ltd. Other chemical reagents were provided by Shanghai Aladdin Biochemical Technology Co. Ltd. (China). All reagents were directly used without any further treatment. Distilled water was purchased from Watsons. <header>Zeolites synthesis<text>The molar composition of gel precursor for synthesizing parent EU-1 zeolite (SiO2/Al2O3 = 60, i.e., Si/Al = 30) was 8 Na2O : 1 Al2O3 : 60 SiO2 : 6 HMBr2 : 1765 H2O. The detailed procedure was described as follows: 2.7 g SiO2 gel was first dropped in 6.48 g distilled water at ambient temperature, which was then mixed homogeneously with stirring at 550 rpm and 60 C. The Na-type EU-1, with mass percentage of 0.2 % based on the weight of gel precursor, was used as the crystal seeds and added into the above mixture to shorten the crystallization time. This mixed solution was recorded as solution A. After precrystallization for 3 h, 0.049 g NaAlO2, 0.172 g NaOH and 0.651 g HMBr2 were dissolved in distilled water and mixed well, which was recorded as solution B. Then the solution B was dropped into solution A, and the mixture was continued to stir for another 3 h. Then the gel precursor was poured into a Teflon-sealed stainless-steel reactor for crystallization at 170 C for 72 h. Afterwards, the resulting solid products were collected by centrifugation and washed with distilled water for three times, finally dried at 100 C overnight. In order to reduce the crystal sizes of EU-1 zeolite, the organosilane reagent (with the amount of 0.15 g or 0.30 g, corresponding to 1.3 % or 2.6 % of the total mass of gel precursor) was slowly dropped into the solution A to functionalize the protozeolitic units. The other procedures followed the same for the synthesis of the parent zeolite. The solution A obtained under different synthesis conditions were abbreviated as 0–60 C-3 h-SA, 0.15–60 C-3 h-SA and 0.30–60 C-3 h-SA. The gel precursors comprised solution A and solution B were recorded as 0–60 C-6 h-G, 0.15–60 C-6 h-G and 0.30–60 C-6 h-G, respectively (0, 0.15 and 0.30 represented the addition amount of TPOAC). In order to study the variation of relative crystallinities and morphologies of zeolite samples prepared with different crystallization time, the gel precursors were hydrothermally treated for various time periods (24 h, 30 h, 36 h, 48 h and 72 h, respectively). The samples obtained with different crystallization time were labelled as 0-EU-1–24 h, 0.15-EU-1–36 h, 0.30-EU-1–72 h, etc. The SDA of these zeolite samples was not removed. The 0-EU-1–72 h, 0.15-EU-1–72 h and 0.30-EU-1–72 h zeolite samples were calcined at 550 C for 8 h to remove the organic template, and the suffix “cal” was included in the abbreviation to indicate the SDA of zeolite was removed by calcination (e.g., 0.15-EU-1–72 h-cal, Na-type zeolites). These Na-type zeolites were converted into NH4-type zeolites by ion exchanging with 1 M NH4Cl solution at 90 C for 2 h, and this process was repeated for three times. The white solid products were separated from the mixed solution by centrifugation and washed with distilled water for three times. The precipitates were dried in the oven at 80 C for 10 h and then calcined at 550 C for 5 h to obtain the H-type zeolites. The suffix “H” indicated that the zeolite sample was obtained by ion exchange (e.g., 0-EU-1-H). To study the interaction between TPOAC and Al species, the verified experiment was proceeded under the same conditions for synthesizing parent EU-1 zeolite. The gel precursors were obtained in the absence of SiO2 gel and crystal seeds in order to exclude the influence of silicon resource, with similar precrystallization and crystallization treatments.

text: <header>Synthesis of hierarchical ZSM-5 zeolite<text>The procedure of hierarchical ZSM-5 zeolite synthesis can been found in our previous works (Xu et al., 2018; Zhang et al., 2017, 2018), TPAOH was used as a micropore template, and APTES was used as a mesopore template. The ZSM-5 precursor solution was prepared in a molar ratio of 100 SiO2: 1 Al2O3: 1500 TEOS: 25 TPAOH: 5 APTES: 2500 H2O. The specific synthesis steps were as follows: Firstly, TPAOH, aluminum nitrate nonahydrate solution and TEOS were sequentially added to the flask and mixed homogeneously, the obtained solution was heated with constant stirring at 363 K for 12 h, and aged at room temperature for 12 h. Then, APTES was added to the flask and mixed homogeneously, and the solution was heated with constant stirring at 363 K for another 8 h to obtain the ZSM-5 precursor solution. The precursor solution was transferred into stainless steel autoclave for hydrothermal crystallization at 443 K for 120 h. The obtained product was centrifugally washed and dried at 353 K for 12 h, and the original hierarchical ZSM-5 zeolite could be obtained after calcination at 873 K for 8 h, which was marked HZ.<header>Chemical liquid deposition of SiO<text>First of all, original hierarchical ZSM-5 zeolite about 2.0 g was added to the flask, and TEOS/n-hexane precursor solution was prepared according to the mass ratio of SiO2/ZSM-5 = 5 wt%. The precursor solution was added to the flask and uniformly mixed with the zeolite powder, and then heated with constant stirring at 333 K for 2 h. After centrifugal washing, the obtained product was dried at 353 K for 12 h, and calcined at 873 K for 6 h. As shown in Scheme 1 , the above operation was repeated (i.e., multiple chemical liquid depositions) to obtain SiO2 layers with specific thicknesses over hierarchical ZSM-5 zeolites, which were named HZ-X-CLD (X represents the number of SiO2 deposition cycles, X = 1, 3, 6). It was worth noting that TEOS has a molecular size of 10.3 Å, which is much larger than the micropore size of ZSM-5 zeolite. Therefore, TEOS molecules are not able to enter the internal micropores of zeolite particles during chemical liquid deposition, only grafting on the hydroxyl group over external surface, thus ultimately the formation of SiO2 layer after high temperature calcination will not block the internal micropore structure of zeolite particles.

text: Tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS, SiO2 ≥ 28.0 wt%), Aluminium iso-propoxide (Al(iso-pr)3, ≥ 98.0 wt%), tetrapropylammonium hydroxide (TPAOH, 40.0 wt% solution), tetramethylammonium hydroxide (TMAOH, 25.0 wt% solution), sodium hydroxide (NaOH, ≥ 98.0 wt%), zinc nitrate hexahydrate (Zn(NO3)2·6H2O, 99 wt%) and ammonium chloride (NH4Cl, ≥99.5 wt%) are all analytically pure, purchased from Aladdin Chemistry Co., LTD and directly used without any additional treatment. Ultra-pure water is provided by the water plant of East China University of Science and Technology. Propane (C3H8, >99.5 vol%) and nitrogen (N2, >99.9 vol%) were provided by Shanghai Pujiang Special Gas Co., LTD. <header>Preparation methods<text>ZSM-5 zeolite with one-dimensional fins on the (010) plane was prepared by hydrothermal method using TPAOH and TMAOH as co-templates. In detail, required amounts of TEOS, Al(iso-pr)3, TPAOH and TMAOH were added into ultra-pure water and the mixture was stirred for 4 h till a clear sol was obtained. The sol with the composition of 1 TEOS: 1/30 Al(iso-pr)3: 0.34 TPAOH: 0.1 TMAOH: 30 H2O was then crystallized in a Teflon-lined autoclave at 170 C for 72 h under tumbling of 30 r/min and the white precipitates were recovered via centrifugation at 5000 r/min, after which the solid products were elevated to 550 C by 2 C/min and calcined for 6 h in a muffle furnace. The as-synthesized finned ZSM-5 samples were indexed as Z5-TMA, wherein TMA denotes to TMAOH. For comparison, conventional micron-sized ZSM-5 was synthesized by hydrothermal method with the precursor composition of 1 TEOS: 1/30 Al(iso-pr)3: 0.2 TPAOH: 0.1 NaOH: 40 H2O. In a typical batch, NaOH, TPAOH, and Al(iso-pr)3 were charged into ultra-pure water under vigorous stirring till the solution is clear; then TEOS is added and the mixture is stirred for another 3 h to fulfil a complete hydrolysis; in the following the white gel was transferred into a Teflon-lined autoclave to proceed static hydrothermal treatment at 170 C for 72 h; thereafter the crystallization was quenched by tapping water and the products were filtered till neutral and dried at 110 C overnight; finally the collected white powders were elevated to 550 C by 2 C/min and calcined for 6 h in a muffle furnace. The obtained Na-form ZSM-5 were exchanged in 1 M NH4Cl solutions and calcined again, and this exchange-calcination process was repeated twice to acquire the H-form ZSM-5 samples. Conventional ZSM-5 sample were labelled as Z5-Na, wherein Na indicates NaOH. Zn loaded ZSM-5 catalysts were prepared by impregnation method, briefly, Zn(NO3)2·6H2O and ultra-pure water of required amounts were mixed with 1 g Z5-Na or Z5-TMA, then the slurry was aged at ambient environment for 24 h and dried at 120 C for 12 h, the powders were subjected to calcination employing identical procedures with the above-mentioned ones. 2 wt% Zn loaded samples were named as Zn/Z5-Na or Zn/Z5-TMA according to the supports used. In special cases, H-form Z5-Na were added into the sol of Z5-TMA as seed before hydrothermal treatment. In the crystallization mechanism study, the amount of TMAOH or TPAOH may vary but the total concentration of OH– were kept constant (OH–/Si/H2O = 0.44/1/30). These samples were named as xPyM wherein P denotes to TPAOH and M denotes to TMAOH, for example, the name 0.44P0M indicates a TPAOH/Si ratio of 0.44 is used with the absence of TMAOH. In the crystallization period study, the solid products were extracted by centrifugation from the autoclaves periodically.

text: NaY zeolites (Crystallinity, 90%) were purchased from Nankai University Catalyst Co., Ltd. (China), the ammonium sulfate ((NH4)2SO4), ammonium bifluoride (NH4HF2, purity >99.99%), ammonium hydroxide (NH4OH) and cetyltrimethyl ammonium bromide (CTAB) were purchased from Aladdin reagent Co., Ltd. (China). <header>Modification treatment of USY<text>The preparation details of the USY and NH4HF2-etched USY samples was described in our previous reports [16]. In surfactant-templating process, 1.00 g NH4HF2-etched USY in 50 mL of 0.5 M NH4OH solution containing 2 mM CTAB was stirred for 2 h, and the mixture was heated at 150 C by a autoclave for 12 h. Then, the solid was washed until the filtrate is neutral and dried at 80 C for 12 h. Next, the dried product was first heated at 550 C for 2 h in an nitrogen atmosphere, and then heated for another 2 h in an air atmosphere. The size-controlled USY zeolites (NH4HF2-etched USY-s) were obtained.

NaY zeolites were purchased from Nankai University Catalyst Co., Ltd. (China), the oxalic acid (H2C2O4), ammonium bifluoride (NH4HF2, purity > 99.99 %), ammonium hydroxide (NH4OH), decyltrimethylammonium bromide (C13H30BrN) and cetyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB) were purchased from Aladdin reagent Co., Ltd. (China). <header>Dealumination modification of NaY zeolite<text>H2C2O4 and NH4HF2 were selected as de-aluminizing agent to obtain irregular mesopores, respectively. In H2C2O4 etching process, 5.00 g NaY in 100 mL of 0.15 M H2C2O4 solution was stirred for 30 min, then the reaction temperature was raised to 95 ℃, and the solution was maintained with stirring for 6 h. The production was washed until the filtrate was neutral and dried at 80 C for 12 h to obtain the dealuminated NaY zeolite (H2C2O4-etched NaY). In NH4HF2 etching process, 5.00 g NaY was dealuminated by 100 mL of 0.3 M NH4HF2 solution, then subsequent operation was consistent with the oxalic acid etching process. The obtained dealuminated NaY is named as the NH4HF2-etched NaY, and the yield of NH4HF2-etched NaY is 82 %.<header>Surfactant-templating treatment of NaY zeolite<text>In surfactant-templating process, 2 g H2C2O4-etched NaY or NH4HF2-etched NaY, and 4 mM surfactant (C13H30BrN, CTAB) were stirred in 100 mL of 0.5 M NH4OH solution for 30 min, and the mixture was heated at 150 C by an autoclave for 12 h. The solid was washed until the filtrate is neutral and dried at 80 C for 12 h. Next, the dried product was heated in nitrogen and then air at 550 C for 2 h, respectively. The prepared sample is named for xx-etched NaY-C10, xx-etched NaY-C16 when C13H30BrN or CTAB is used as the surfactant, respectively. The yield of surfactant-templating process can reach 80 %, and the yield of heat treatment can reach 90 %. For example, the final yield of NH4HF2-etched NaY-C16 is about 59 % when that of parent NaY is set to 100 %.

<header>Preparation of alkali-modified ZSM-5<text>The zeolite used in this work was a commercial ZSM-5 with a SiO2/Al2O3 molar ratio of 25.1 g of ZSM-5 underwent treatment with 20 mL of 1 mol/L NaOH aqueous solution for 6 h under stirring conditions. Following this, the mixture underwent suction filtration and was rinsed with ultrapure water until reaching a neutral pH. Subsequently, the alkali-treated ZSM-5 was transferred to a pristine beaker and underwent drying at 80 C for 24 h. The untreated sample is obtained as ZSM-5(P) and the samples treated with NaOH aqueous solutions are obtained as ZSM-5(AT). The alkaline modification method is relatively mild and produces less harmful substances.<header>Synthesis of chitin modified ZSM-5(AT) (chitin/ZSM-5(AT))<text>1 g of chitin powder was dispersed in a water-based solvent comprising 11 wt% NaOH and 4 wt% urea (50 g), and stirred evenly. Afterward, the mixture was frozen at -30 C in a cooling trap for 3 h and then thawed at 2 C. This freezing/thawing process was iterated three times to yield a transparent mixed chitin solution. 8 g of ZSM-5(AT) powder was then added to this solution and stirred for 30 min under continuous magnetic stirring to ensure that ZSM-5(AT) and chitin were completely and uniformly mixed. 60 mL of anhydrous ethanol was introduced into the mixed solution and left for 15 min. After the chitin and ZSM-5(AT) composite formed a colloid, the colloid was transferred to a clean beaker with 60 mL of anhydrous ethanol and immersed for 24 h. The colloid underwent suction filtration and was rinsed with ultrapure water until neutral and freeze-dried for 24 h for later use. This material obtained is expressed as “Chitin/ZSM-5(AT)”. Chitin itself is a biodegradable green material. In addition, to avoid possible organic solvent residues and causing harm to the environment, a green solvent is chosen for dissolving chitin, which is more environmentally friendly compared with other organic solvents.<header>Synthesis of NZVI@Chitin-modified ZSM-5 (NZVI@C-ZSM) and NZVI@ZSM<text>In a 250 mL beaker, 3.72 g of FeSO4·7H2O were dissolved in 45 mL of ultrapure water with stirring until completely dissolved. And then 0.5 g Chitin/ZSM-5(AT) was introduced into the mixture and stirred for 30 min. Subsequently, 30 mL of a 1.2 mol/L KBH4 solution was added dropwise, and let stand for 30 min. For immobilization of NZVI, Fe3+ ions are initially anchored onto the functional groups of chitin via adsorption. Fe3+ ions can interact with the N–H or CO groups of the hydroxyl and acetamide groups in chitin, forming chelates (K. V. SandV., 2021). Subsequently, the anchored Fe3+ ions are in situ reduced by adding KBH4, forming NZVI on the chitin (Chen et al., 2023a). The entirety of the synthesis procedure was conducted without the need for N2 protection (Fig. 1 ). The synthesized material was isolated via suction filtration and underwent triple washing with ultrapure water and ethanol. This material obtained is designated as “NZVI@C-ZSM”. The composite material without surfactant chitin was prepared using the same method. All other steps were consistent with the preparation of NZVI@C-ZSM, except that 0.5 g of Chitin/ZSM-5(AT) was replaced with 0.5 g of ZSM-5(AT), and the resulting material was named NZVI@ZSM.

The sodium hydroxide (NaOH, purity > 99.99%), sodium silicate (Na2O·nSiO2, purity = 20%), sodium aluminate (NaAlO2, purity = 99%), aluminium sulfate octadecahydrate (Al2(SO4)3·18H2O, purity = 99%) and carbon disulfide (CS2, purity = 99.5%) were purchased from Aladdin reagent Co., Ltd. (China). The activated carbon was purchased from Fuchen Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. (Tianjin). The conventional NaZSM-5, conventional NaY, nanocrystal NaZSM-5, and NaSAPO-34 zeolites were purchased from Nankai University Catalyst Co., Ltd. (China). They were denoted as NaZSM-5, NaY, nano-NaZSM-5, and NaSAPO-34, respectively. <header>Preparations of alkali-treated zeolites and nano-crystal NaY zeolites<text>The alkali-treated NaZSM-5 or alkali-treated NaY samples were prepared by treating the conventional NaZSM-5 or conventional NaY in the NaOH solution at 353 K. Here, the weight ratio of zeolite to NaOH solution for alkaline treatment was 1.0/30.0 (wt./wt.). Then, the treated samples were filtrated and carefully washed with deionized water until the pH ≈ 7, and then dried in an oven at 393 K for 12 h and subsequently calcined at 793 K for 2 h. The obtained samples were denoted as x-yAT-NaZSM-5 or x-yAT-NaY. Here, x was the hourage of alkaline-treatment time, and y was the concentration value of the NaOH solution used in alkaline treatment. AT means alkaline treatment. For example, 3-0.1AT-NaZSM-5 was the sample prepared by treating NaZSM-5 in a 0.1 mol/L NaOH solution for 3 h at 353 K. The nano-crystal NaY was synthesized as the following procedures. At first, the structure-directing agent with a molar composition of 13.8 Na2O: 1.0 Al2O3 : 10.8 SiO2 : 226.0 H2O (molar ratio), was prepared by firstly mixing the required amounts of NaAlO2, NaOH, sodium silicate (Na2O·nSiO2) and distilled water together, and subsequently ageing at 305 K for 16 h in an oven. Secondly, the gel for preparing nano-crystal NaY was prepared by mixing the required amounts of NaAlO2, NaOH, C2H5OH, Al2(SO4)3·18H2O, sodium silicate, distilled water, and structure-directing agent together. Its molar composition was 6.5 Na2O : 1.0 Al2O3 : 10.1 SiO2 : 220 H2O: f C2H5OH (molar ratio). After stirring for 2 h, the obtained gel was transferred into a 0.5 L stainless steel autoclave and then hydrothermally treated at 353 K for 16 h. The obtained solid sample was filtered and repeatedly washed with deionized water until pH ≈ 7, then dried at 393 K for 12 h and subsequently calcined at 793 K for 2 h. This prepared nano-crystal NaY was denoted as nano-NaY-f. Here f was the molar ratio of C2H5OH to Al2O3 for the synthesis gel. For example, the nano-NaY-0.909 was the nano-crystal NaY synthesized by using a gel with a molar composition of 6.5 Na2O : 1.0 Al2O3 : 10.1 SiO2 : 220 H2O : 0.909 C2H5OH.

<header>Synthesis of ZSM-23 zeolites<text>ZSM-23 zeolites were hydrothermally synthesized utilizing IPA, colloidal silica (40 wt%), sodium aluminum (Al2O3 ≥ 41.0 %), sodium hydroxide and distilled water as raw materials. The gel composition was: 100 SiO2: 1.2 Al2O3: 7.0 NaOH: 200 IPA: 30H2O. In a typical batch, 0.37 g NaOH was firstly dissolved in 56.00 g distilled water, followed by the addition of 0.40 g NaAlO2. The clear solution was vigorously stirred for 10 min, and 20.00 g colloidal silicate was dropwise charged to proceed another 4 h of stirring. Next, 15.66 g IPA as OSDA which has been previously dispersed in 16.00 g H2O, was dropped into the obtained white slurry. The obtained mixture was sealed in a Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave at 160 C for 96 h under tumbling (30 rpm). The resultant slurry was washed with distilled water, then the products were dried at 110 C for 12 h in a convection oven. The as-prepared zeolites were calcined at 550 C for 6 h to remove the occluded organic templates and then ion-exchanged for three times with 1 M NH4Cl at 80 C for 30 min. The NH4-type ZSM-23zeolite were finally calcined again at 550 C for 6 h to harvest H-type zeolites, which was named as Z23 for abbreviation.<header>Vapor-Phase Transport (VPT) treatment of ZSM-23 zeolites<text>The VPT treatment was carried out in the autoclave reactor with a capacity of 100 ml at 160 C for 2 days. A small 20 ml Teflon beaker containing 1 g Z23 was put into the autoclave within a layer of liquid at the bottom (2.2 g water and 0 g, 6.5 g, 13.0 g IPA). After the VPT treatment, the autoclave was cooled with tap water and the solid was washed with distilled water. After drying 12 h at 110 C, calcination at 550 C for 6 h was carried out to remove organic residuals. The ZSM-23 treated with pure water was named as ZW (ZSM-23 treated by water), while other samples treated with IPA solutions were labelled as Z50I or Z100I, denoting to ZSM-23 treated by IPA solutions of 50 M and 100 M, respectively.

text: <header>Catalyst preparation and characterization<text>HZSM-5 zeolite (SiO2/Al2O3 = 25) was purchased from Nankai University Catalyst Corp, China. Prior to the work, it was calcined in a tubular furnace at 550 C for 5 h to remove impurities and absorbed water. HZSM-5 was further modified with monometallic Co or bimetallic Mo-Co, Ni-Co via wet impregnation method. The modified HZSM-5 was denoted as Co-H-5, Mo/Co-H-5 and Ni/Co-H-5, respectively. Co-H-5 (Co loading: 3 wt%) was prepared by impregnating 24 g of HZSM-5 in an aqueous solution of 3.6 g of Co(NO3)2·6H2O. The mixture was vibrated in ultrasonic instrument for 2 h and impregnated overnight in vacuum dryer to enhance the dispersion of Co ions into the pore. It was then dried at 60 C for 4 h and 110 C for 5 h. Finally, the solid was calcined at 600 C for 6 h. The metal-Co loading was calculated via the mass ratio between metal-Co and HZSM-5 support. The bimetallic Mo-Co or Ni-Co catalysts were similarly prepared by impregnating Co-H-5 support. 16 g of Co-H-5 was divided into two parts and impregnated in 3.1 g of (NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O and 1.2 g of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O hydrate solution, respectively. All bimetallic catalysts were based on 3 wt% of Co content [34]. For mesoporous HZSM-5, the support was slowly added into 0.2 M NaOH solution and stirred at 65 C for 1 h. It was then filtered and washed with distilled water until neutral. The filter cake was dried at 110 C for 24 h. The prepared Na-form ZSM-5 was ion-exchanged with 1 M NH4NO3 solution to prepare H-form HZSM-5 (AT-HZSM-5). Metal-loaded AT-HZSM-5 was also prepared via wet impregnation method. The Co, Mo-Co and Ni-Co modified AT-HZSM-5 was denoted as AT-Co/H-5, AT-Mo/Co-H-5 and AT-Ni/Co-H-5, respectively. The catalysts were characterized by scanning electron microscopy (SEM), inductively coupled plasma-atomic emission spectrometric (ICP-AES), N2 adsorption-desorption instrument, X-ray diffraction (XRD), temperature programmed desorption of ammonia (NH3-TPD) and Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy. The corresponding specification and test program were demonstrated in the Supplementary Material.

Citric acid (99.5 %), glycerol (99.0 %), and nickel(II) nitrate hexahydrate (99.99 %) were supplied by Sigma-Aldrich. Cetyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB), nitric acid (65 %), sodium bicarbonate (>99.7 %), sodium carbonate (>99.5 %), sodium hydroxide (>98 %), sodium sulphate (>99.0 %), and sulfuric acid (98 %) were purchased from Merck. Ammonia (99.99 %) and nitrogen (99.99 %) were supplied by SIAD and Alphagaz 1, respectively. Copper(II) nitrate hemipentahydrate (98 %) was purchased from Riedel de Haen. NaY (NaY CBV-100 Si/Al = 2.8) and NH4ZSM5 (CBV 3024E Si/Al = 15) zeolites in powder form were provided by Zeolyst International. <header>Preparation of hierarchical zeolites<text>The commercial NaY (Y_micr) and NH4ZSM5 (ZSM5_micr) zeolites were modified through a surfactant-mediated desilication treatment, optimised from a method reported in previous works, in order to obtain the hierarchical forms [30,31]. Prior to desilication, the zeolites were submitted to different pretreatments. Y_micr was acid-washed with a 10 wt% citric acid solution to fragilize the structure, using 2 mL of solution (i.e., ca. 1 mmol of citric acid) for 1 g of zeolite. After around 17 h under stirring at room temperature (RT), the solid was recovered by filtration, washed with distilled water, and dried at 110 C overnight. In the case of ZSM5_micr, before desilication, the structure was fragilized in two consecutive steps: first the zeolite was dispersed in a NaOH solution (1 M, 4 mL per gram of zeolite), stirred for 1 h at 80 C and then recovered by filtration, washed with distilled water, and dried at 110 C overnight; subsequently, the resulting powder was dispersed in a H2SO4 solution (0.6 M, 4 mL per gram of zeolite) for 3 h at 80 C, under stirring and finally recovered by filtration, washed with distilled water, and dried at 110 C overnight. The pre-treated Y and ZSM5 zeolites were then used to prepare the hierarchical structures through the surfactant-mediated desilication process. Typically, a dispersion was prepared with the ratio of 64 mL of a NaOH solution (0.37 M) and 0.7 g of CTAB for each gram of zeolite. After stirring for 20 min at RT and adjusting the pH to 11 with a 2 M HCl solution, the dispersion (ca. 25 mL) was transferred into a 50 mL stainless steel PTFE-lined autoclave and heated at 150 C under autogenous pressure for 6 h. The obtained solid was then recovered by filtration, washed with distilled water, and dried overnight at 110 C.<header>Preparation of metal-exchanged zeolites<text>For the preparation of the metal-exchanged zeolites, Ni and Cu ions were inserted into the porous structure of both parent (Y_micr and ZSM5_micr) and hierarchical zeolites (Y_hier and ZSM5_hier) via an ion-exchange procedure. In a typical procedure, 1 g of the starting zeolite was suspended in 50 mL of a solution containing both metal precursors (nitrates), each at a concentration equal to 0.001 M, and stirred at 300 rpm for 24 h at RT. The obtained solid was then recovered by filtration, washed with distilled water, dried at 80 C for 12 h, and finally calcined at 350 C for 4 h.<header>Preparation of the modified electrodes<text>In order to test the metal-exchanged zeolites as electrocatalysts for GEOR, they were used for the preparation of the zeolite-modified electrodes. A Toray carbon paper with a surface of 2 × 4 cm2 was first glued to a platinum electrode with conductive carbon cement, and then dried for 24 h at RT. Next, 20 mg of the metal-exchanged zeolite were mixed in a Nafion/water solution (180 μL of Nafion and 180 μL of type-1) and the suspension was homogenised in an ultrasonic bath for 20 min. Finally, the suspension was deposited on the Toray carbon paper and dried for 24 h at RT.

text: <header>Alkaline treatment of Y zeolite<text>Two Y zeolites with different degrees of intracrystalline mesoporosity were used. The parent zeolite was a commercial Y zeolite (CBV 760, Zeolyst International, protonic form). The modified sample was the result of the following alkaline treatment on the parent zeolite [14,27–29]. 10 g of zeolite were suspended in 300 mL of a NaOH solution (0.10 M) and the suspension was stirred during 15 min at room temperature. Then, a 1.00 M HCl solution was added to the suspension to reach a final pH of 2.00 in order to quench the alkaline leaching. The thus desilicated zeolite was separated from the solution by filtration and submitted to three cycles of ion exchange using 5 mL of 0.50 M NH4Cl solution per gram of zeolite. The ion-exchanged zeolite was then thoroughly washed using deionized water, dried in an oven during 16 h at 110 C and finally calcined in a muffle oven during 4 h at 550 C in order to obtain the zeolite in its acid form. The parent and desilicated zeolites were named Y-00 and Y-10, respectively. Both the modified and untreated zeolites were hydrothermally stabilized by steaming during 5 h at 788 C (100% steam). The steamed zeolites were named Y-00-S and Y-10-S, respectively, in concordance with their parent zeolites.

The chemicals in this research including ammonium bifluoride (NH4HF2, Merck Chemical Co.), iron (III) nitrate (Fe(NO3)3.9H2O, Merck Chemical Co.), gallium (III) nitrate (Ga(NO3)3. XH2O, Sigma-Aldrich Chemical Co.), cerium (III) nitrate (Ce(NO3)3.6H2O, Merck Chemical Co.), lanthanum (III) nitrate (La(NO3)3.6H2O, Merck Chemical Co.), zirconium (IV) oxynitrate hydrate (ZrO(NO3)2. xH2O, Sigma-Aldrich Chemical Co.), and ammonium nitrate (NH4NO3, Merck Chemical Co.) were of analytical grade and used as received. <header>Modification method for dealumination of zeolite and incorporation of metal<text>The parent Na-ZSM-5 zeolite catalyst with a Si/Al ratio of 120 was obtained from The Research Institute of Petroleum Industry (RIPI). Before use, the parent Na-ZSM-5 zeolite catalyst (coded as “parent”) was converted to the ammonium form of zeolite (NH4-ZSM-5) by three consecutive ion exchange steps using 2.0 M NH4NO3 solution ( 1 g Z e o l i t e 20 m l N H 4 N O 3 ) for 3 h at 75 C. The powder was then calcined for 4 h at 550 C to obtain the H-form zeolite (H-ZSM-5). The M/ZSM-5 catalysts (M: Fe, Ga, Zr, Ce, and La) were synthesized by treating the parent with NH4HF2/metal solution. The experiment is described using Fe metal as an example. A mixture with a 2:3 M ratio of Fe(NO3)3: NH4HF2 and Fe/Al ratio of 1 was dispersed in 250 ml of deionized water and the dispersion obtained was then added to a known amount of the parent powder. After stirring for 10 min, a uniform solution was obtained, which was refluxed for 24 h at 90 C at 240 rpm under the lab hood. After cooling the mixture at ambient temperature, the solid was filtered, washed thoroughly with hot deionized water, and dried at 100 C for 4 h. Finally, the sample was calcined at 600 C for 4 h. This catalyst was coded as Fe–F-Z, based on the metal name-F-Z (Metal-F-Z).

text: <header>Catalysts preparation<text>H5 was purchased from the Catalyst Plant of Nankai University with SiO2/Al2O3 mole ratio of 25. The catalyst was pulverized followed by calcination at 550 C for 5 h in muffle furnace to remove the template agent. According to the Fig. 1 , the H5 was modified through two steps. Firstly, the H5 was treated by 0.2 mol/L NaOH solution for 30 min in water bath at 60 C. Subsequently, the catalyst was filtered and washed with distilled water until it was neutralized. Then it was dried at 110 C for 24 h. In order to obtain the H-form zeolite, the Na-form zeolite was adopted ion exchanged with 1 mol/L NH4Cl solution. The treated H5 was named AT0.2/H5. Secondly, the zirconium nitrate pentahydrate was dissolve in 50 mL distilled water. Then the AT0.2/H5 was added to the zirconium nitrate pentahydrate solution. The mixture was ultrasonic for 3 h and then dried at 80 C for 24 h. The dried solid was calcined at 300 C for 3 h. The obtained sample was mixed with different concentrations of sulfuric acid following by drying at 110 C for 12 h, and then calcining at 600 C for 5 h. The solid acid catalyst was obtained and denoted as AT0.2/SZxH5, where x represents the molar ratio of S/Zr (S: sulfuric acid and Zr:ZrO2), that is, x = 2:1, 4:1, 6:1 and 8:1. All the catalysts were stored in dry environment to avoid water adsorption. The prepared catalysts were characterized using several analytical tools such as X-ray diffraction (XRD), N2 adsorption–desorption, NH3-Temperature programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) and scanning electron microscope (SEM). The test procedure of instruments were also reported in literature [17,23–25].

<header>Materials preparation<text>A commercial H-ZSM-5 sample (Grace Davison; Si/Al = 17) was used as a parent material to prepare hierarchical materials. Prior to treatment, the parent zeolite was brought into the ammonium form by three successive ion exchanges at 333 K for 6 h with 1 M NH4Cl aqueous solution (20g of solution/g of zeolite). In the first set of experiments, the concentration of NH4F solution was kept constant, and the amount of NH4-ZSM-5 was varied. In contrast, in the second set of experiments the concentration of the NH4F solution was varied, keeping the concentration of zeolite constant. Thus, not only the NH4F concentration but also the solid:liquid (zeolite:solution) ratio was varied. The first set of experiments has been performed as follows: 8 g of NH4F (98%, Sigma-Aldrich) has been dissolved in 12 g of distilled water under mechanical stirring (400 rpm) at 323 K. Then, between 1 and 4 g of NH4-ZSM-5 was introduced into the solution and let under mechanical stirring (400 rpm) for 2 h at 323 K (the following table - <R><C>[EMPTY]<C>First set of experiments<C>First set of experiments<C>First set of experiments<C>Second set of experiments<C>Second set of experiments<C>Second set of experiments<C>Second set of experiments<C>Second set of experiments<C>Second set of experiments<C>Second set of experiments<R><C>m(NH4<C>1<C>2<C>4<C>1<C>1<C>1<C>1<C>1<C>1<C>1<R><C>m(NH4<C>8<C>8<C>8<C>8<C>6<C>4<C>2<C>1<C>0.5<C>0.25<R><C>m(water) (g)<C>12<C>12<C>12<C>12<C>12<C>12<C>12<C>12<C>12<C>12<R><C>NH4<C>40<C>40<C>40<C>40.0<C>33.3<C>25.0<C>14.3<C>7.7<C>4.0<C>2.0<Cap>Amount of ZSM-5, NH44</Cap> ). Intermediate samples have been taken out after 0.5, 1.0, and 1.5 h of reaction. Finally, the resulting materials have been thoroughly washed with distilled water and dry at 373 K overnight. In the second set of experiments, between 8 and 0.25 g of NH4F (98%, Sigma-Aldrich) was dissolved in 12 g of distilled water under mechanical stirring (400 rpm) at 323 K. Then, 1 g of NH4-ZSM-5 was introduced into the solution and let under mechanical stirring (400 rpm) for 2 h at 323 K (the following table - <R><C>[EMPTY]<C>First set of experiments<C>First set of experiments<C>First set of experiments<C>Second set of experiments<C>Second set of experiments<C>Second set of experiments<C>Second set of experiments<C>Second set of experiments<C>Second set of experiments<C>Second set of experiments<R><C>m(NH4<C>1<C>2<C>4<C>1<C>1<C>1<C>1<C>1<C>1<C>1<R><C>m(NH4<C>8<C>8<C>8<C>8<C>6<C>4<C>2<C>1<C>0.5<C>0.25<R><C>m(water) (g)<C>12<C>12<C>12<C>12<C>12<C>12<C>12<C>12<C>12<C>12<R><C>NH4<C>40<C>40<C>40<C>40.0<C>33.3<C>25.0<C>14.3<C>7.7<C>4.0<C>2.0<Cap>Amount of ZSM-5, NH44</Cap>). Intermediate samples were taken out after 0.5, 1.0, and 1.5 h of reaction. The resulting materials have been thoroughly washed with distilled water and dried at 373 K overnight. The samples were denoted NH4F(X)-ZSM-5(Y)-Z, where X and Y respectively stand for the weight of NH4F and NH4-ZSM-5 in gram per 12 g of water, and Z is the reaction time in hours. The maximum yield of modified zeolite (%Ymax) has been calculated from the total amount of material collected as follow: % Y max = ∑ m t m i n i × 100 where mt is the weight of zeolite taken for different treatment times and mini is the initial weight of zeolite.<header>Study of the influence of the weight concentration of zeolite<text>In the first part of the study, from 1 to 4 g of zeolite was treated in 20 g of a 40 wt% NH4F solution (see the following table - <R><C>[EMPTY]<C>First set of experiments<C>First set of experiments<C>First set of experiments<C>Second set of experiments<C>Second set of experiments<C>Second set of experiments<C>Second set of experiments<C>Second set of experiments<C>Second set of experiments<C>Second set of experiments<R><C>m(NH4<C>1<C>2<C>4<C>1<C>1<C>1<C>1<C>1<C>1<C>1<R><C>m(NH4<C>8<C>8<C>8<C>8<C>6<C>4<C>2<C>1<C>0.5<C>0.25<R><C>m(water) (g)<C>12<C>12<C>12<C>12<C>12<C>12<C>12<C>12<C>12<C>12<R><C>NH4<C>40<C>40<C>40<C>40.0<C>33.3<C>25.0<C>14.3<C>7.7<C>4.0<C>2.0<Cap>Amount of ZSM-5, NH44</Cap> for more details).

<header>Preparation of catalysts<text>HZSM-5 powder with Si/Al = 25 was supplied by Nanjing refinery Co., Ltd (China) and calcined in air condition at 550 C for 4 h before use. Desilication was carried out by mixing 7.5 g HZSM-5 with 150 mL of 0.3 M NaOH aqueous solution at 80 C for 2 h under vigorously stirring condition. Afterwards, the cooled suspension was separated by filtration, washed with deionized water until pH reached to 7, and dried at 100 C overnight. The desilicated Na-ZSM-5 zeolite was transferred into H-form ZSM-5 by three consecutive conventional ion exchanges with 0.8 M NH4NO3 solution at 80 C for under stirring condition 8 h and calcined at 550 C for 4 h under the flow of synthetic air. Dealumination by steaming was performed in a fixed bed reactor. The catalyst (ca. 1.6 g) was charged into a quartz tube. After that, steaming treatment was conducted at 450 C under a flow of pure water vapours (WHSV = 12 h-1) for 3 h. Here, the separate treated HZSM-5 zeolites were labeled as 0.3 M NaOH/HZSM-5 and 3 h 450 C/HZSM-5, and the co-modified zeolite samples were denoted as 0.3 M NaOH/3h 450 C/HZSM-5 and 3 h 450 C/0.3 M NaOH/HZSM-5 according to the sequential order of desilication and steaming treatment, respectively.

<header>Materials<text>The solids used were commercial zeolite H–USY powder (Zeolyst CBV600), zeolite ammonium VUSY POWDER (Zeolyst CBV712), powder zeolite (Zeolyst CBV720), and zeolite H–SDUSY powder (Zeolyst CBV780). Zeolite H-Y was obtained through an ionic interchange of zeolite Na-Y (Zeolyst CBV 100) with a 1 M aqueous solution of NH4NO3 (Panreac, 98.5% purity) at 358 K under reflux for 2 h. The solid was then filtered, dried at 373 K for 2 h, and calcined at 823 K for 3 h (heating rate 10 K/min). Table S1 lists some properties of the selected commercial zeolites studied in this work. Mesostructured zeolites were supplied by Laboratorio de Catálisis Heterogénea (LCH) and obtained from commercial zeolites series using the procedure previously reported [35]. Probe aromatic molecules were benzene (Panreac, 99.9% purity), toluene (Merck EMSURE®, >99.9% Purity), o–xylene (TCI, 99.3% purity), m–xylene (TCI, 99.7% purity), p–xylene (TCI, 99.7%) and cumene (Sigma–Aldrich, 99.3% purity). The gases were helium (5.0 UH Praxair, 99.999% Purity), oxygen (Praxair, 99.99% purity), and hydrogen (Praxair, 99.995% Purity). The properties of the selected molecule probes are provided in Table S2.

<header>Synthesis of parent HZSM-5 zeolite<text>Parent HZSM-5 zeolite was synthesized by the hydrothermal method using tetrapropyl ammonium hydroxide (TPAOH, 25%) as a template, tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS, AR) as a silicon source, and aluminum isopropoxide (AIP, AR) as an aluminum source. An appropriate amount of TEOS was added dropwise to 1.0 M TPAOH solution, and then fully stirred at 35℃ for 2 h to form a well-mixed solution. Hydrolyzed AIP in deionized water was then slowly added to the solution. The molar ratio of the gel mixture was 1 TEOS: 0.025 AIP: 0.21 TPAOH: 36 H2O. The mixture was heated and stirred at 85℃ for 3 h to remove alcohol, during which time deionized water was continuously added to maintain the original water level. After that, the alcohol-free mixture was transferred into a hydrothermal crystallization kettle to be crystallized for 72 h at 170 ℃. The crystallized product was separated by a centrifuge and then washed with deionized water to reach a neutral pH. The obtained solid was dried at 100 ℃, and then calcined at 550 ℃ for 6 h in a muffle to obtain the parent HZSM-5 zeolite.<header>Preparation of hierarchical HZSM-5 zeolites<text>Hierarchical HZSM-5 zeolites were prepared by NaOH leaching. Three NaOH solutions with different concentrations (0.1 M, 0.3 M and 0.5 M) were prepared to create hierarchical structures in HZSM-5 crystals. The parent HZSM-5 zeolite was added into NaOH solution at a ratio of 1 g HZSM-5 zeolite to 10 ml NaOH solution. The mixture of HZSM-5 zeolite and NaOH solution was stirred at 80 ℃ for 2 h. After that, the zeolite was separated by a centrifuge, washed to neutrality using deionized water, and then dried at 80 ℃ for 8 h. The dried zeolite was added into a 1.0 M NH4Cl solution at a ratio of 1 g zeolite to 10 ml NH4Cl solution, and then stirred at 80 ℃ for 2 h. The solid was separated by a centrifuge and washed 3 times with deionized water. The washed sample was calcined at 550 ℃ in a muffle for 6 h. The post-treated HZSM-5 zeolites were named as 0.1NaOHZ5, 0.3NaOHZ5 and 0.5NAOHZ5 according to the concentration of NaOH solution, respectively.

text: <header>Materials<text>Iranian mills rice husk ash (RHA) as a silica source, sodium hydroxide (Dr. Mojallali) as an alkali source, aluminum hydroxide (Riedel- de Haën) as an aluminum source, hydrochloric acid (Dr. Mojallali, 37%) for acid treatment and distilled water were employed for the preparation of precursor suspensions. Beta zeolite with Si/Al = 12.5 as an additive in composite zeolite synthesis has also been used. Furthermore, ammonium nitrate (Ghatran shimi) and NaCl (Dr. Mojallali) for zeolite ion exchange and methanol (Dr. Mojallali) as a feed in methanol to gasoline reaction tests were used.

<header>Alkaline treatment of nanozeloite<text>Nanozeolites (Mordenite cliniptilolite) were modified using either sodium hydroxide (NaOH) and sodium hydrogen carbonate (NaHCO3) [47]. A 5 g of nanozeolite was added in 1 M of NaOH or NaHCO3 solution (200 mL) and sonicated for 30 min. After the modified, nanozeolites were washed using distilled water until the pH value become near 7.0. Pristine nanozeolite was represented as NZ, whereas the modified nanozeolite was represented as NZ-X, where X was the modifier, NaOH or NaHCO3.<header>Nanozeolite modified membrane preparation<text>PAN support was prepared using a continuous casting machine. A 200-μm thickness of 15 wt% PAN/NMP solution was cast onto a polyester nonwoven using casting knife. Then, the as-casting membrane was immersed immediately into a water coagulation bath for phase-inversion process. The modified PAN (mPAN) support was fabricated through hydrolysis of the PAN support by immersing into 2 M NaOH solution at 50 C for 30 min. Some –CN groups of the PAN support was converted to –COOH and –CONH2 groups after the hydrolysis. Prior interfacial polymerization, mPAN support was washed by water for several hours [48]. Wet mPAN support was immersed in a 0.5 wt% aqueous DETA solution at room temperature for 1 min. The droplets of aqueous DETA solution that remained on the surface of the mPAN membrane was removed using rubber roller. Then, 0.5 wt% TMC/n-hexane solution was poured on the membrane at room temperature for 1 min. Polyamide layer was formed on top of the mPAN support. This membrane was immersed in methanol for several hours. Afterwards, it was dried at room temperature. This membrane was represented as TFC membranes. Similar methods to prepare TFN membranes with the TFC membranes. For TFN membranes, different types of nanozeolite were added in the TMC/n-hexane solution. Modified membranes were represented as TFN-Y where Y is the nanozeolite used (NZ, NZ- NaOH or NZ- NaHCO3).

<header>Catalyst preparation<text>This study obtained parent HZSM-5 zeolite (Si/Al = 177) from SINOPEC Catalyst Co., Ltd., and named as sample ZSM-5. Sodium hydroxide (NaOH), sodium bicarbonate (NaHCO3), sodium aluminate (NaAlO2), potassium carbonate (K2CO3), sodium carbonate (Na2CO3), and ammonium chloride (NH4Cl) were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagents Co., Ltd. During the representative alkaline treatment, the alkaline solution (100 ml) of a specific concentration was placed within a reflux condenser-equipped flask under 60 C on the water bath. Later, parent sample (10 g) was put in the above solution, followed by 4 h of stirring under a constant temperature. The slurry was then cooled down on the ice-bath, followed by filtration to separate the solid from the solution. Then, distilled water was used to rinse the solid till the filtrate pH was 7. NH4Cl solutions (1.0 M) were utilized for ion-exchange with all the sodium type alkaline treated ZSM-5 samples twice under 90 C, for the sake of replacing Na+ with NH4 +. At last, those zeolites modified were further filtered, rinsed according to previous description and dried for a 4-h period under 120 C. Typically, HZSM-5 zeolites were named exposed to 0.5 M NaOH, K2CO3, Na2CO3 and NaAlO2 as samples ZNaOH, ZK2CO3, ZNa2CO3, and ZNaAlO2, separately, whereas samples treated with 0.2, 0.5, 1.0 and 2.0 M NaHCO3 solutions as samples ZNaHCO3-0.2, ZNaHCO3, ZNaHCO3-1.0 and ZNaHCO3-2.0, respectively.

<header>Synthesis of hierarchical zeolite Y<text>The molar composition of 8Na2O: 0.7Al2O3: 10SiO2: 160H2O: xTPOAC was used, where × is the molar ratio of dimethyloctadecyl[3-(trimethoxysilyl)propyl]ammonium chloride (TPOAC) solution (42 wt% TPOAC in methanol, Sigma-Aldrich), an amphiphilic organosilane template. Briefly, solution A was prepared by dissolving NaOH (99%, Merck) and sodium aluminate (53.0% Al2O3, 42.5% Na2O, Sigma-Aldrich). Solution B was prepared by mixing sodium silicate (26.5% SiO2, 10% Na2O, Sigma-Aldrich) with NaOH and distilled water. Solution A was added dropwise to solution B under vigorous stirring in ice bath for 30 min. After that, the TPOAC solution was added dropwise. The resulting gel solution was stirred for another 1 h before static aging at 25 C for 2 days, followed by crystallization at 80 C for 22 h. After cooled down to room temperature, the solid was washed repeatedly with distilled water via centrifugation (10000 rpm, 30 min) until pH 7 before drying at 70 C overnight. After that, the samples were calcined at 550 C for 6 h, heating rate of 1 C/min. The synthesized catalysts were donated as MYx, where × represent the molar ratio of TPOAC (0.05, 0.15 and 0.25). For comparison, conventional nanosized zeolite Y was also synthesized using the same synthesis method mentioned above without the addition of TPOAC and was denoted as MY0.

text: Al2(SO4)3·18H2O (AR, Tianjin Tianli, China), silica sol (SiO2 26.6 %, Qingdao Yuminyuan, China), KOH (AR, Tianjin Kemiou, China), 1,6-diaminohexane (DAH, AR, Sinopharm, China), polyhexamethylene biguanidine hydrochloride (PHMB, 20 %, Wuxi Jindinglonghua, China) and 5 % Pd(NO3)2 aqueous solution (Shanxi Kaida, China) were used as aluminum, silica, alkaline, conventional template, alternative template sources and metal precursors to prepare ZSM-22 zeolites and Pd/ZSM-22 bifunctional catalysts, respectively. <header>Synthesis of ZSM-22 zeolites and preparation of Pd/ZSM-22 bifunctional catalysts<text>The conventional microporous ZSM-22 zeolite was synthesized by the hydrothermal crystallization method according to Ref. [33]. The KOH and Al2(SO4)3·18H2O were mixed and dissolved in deionized water first, then DAH and silica sol were dropped into the mechanical agitator and stirred vigorously to obtain the precursor gel with mole ratios of SiO2: Al2O3: DAH: OH-: H2O = 1.0: 0.011: 0.4: 0.25: 35.0. The obtained precursor gel was moved into a Teflon autoclave, followed by dynamic crystallization at 160 C and 90 r/min for 34 h. After crystallization, the samples were centrifuged (three times) and dried (110 C) after being cooled to room temperature, followed by calcination at 600 C for 10 h to remove the DAH template. After that, the ZSM-22 sample and 1 M NH4NO3 solution were packed into a three-necked flask and ion-exchanged for 8 h at 80 C to obtain the acid ZSM-22 zeolite, which was denoted as the Z22-D sample. The hierarchical ZSM-22 zeolites were synthesized with almost the same process as that of the Z22-D sample, except that PHMB was employed as the only template instead of DAH and the addition amount of PHMB was SiO2/xPHMB, in which x = 0.001, 0.002 and 0.003. The obtained hierarchical ZSM-22 samples were named Z22-xP when x = 0.001, 0.002 and 0.003. The Pd/ZSM-22 bifunctional catalysts with 0.5 wt% Pd loading were prepared on the corresponding ZSM-22 samples via wetness impregnation with Pd(NO3)2 solution followed by drying overnight and calcination at 600 C in air for 4 h. All catalysts were pressed into flakes with a tableting machine for 3 min. Then, the flake samples were crushed into 20–40 mesh particles and then named Pd/Z22-D and Pd/Z22-xP, respectively.

text: <header>Materials<text>Five Y zeolites were supplied by Dalian Research Institute of Sinopec, which were denoted as Y-1, Y-2, Y-3, Y-4 and Y-5, respectively. Ammonium chloride and pyridine (Py) were purchased from Aladdin's Reagent. Hexane was purchased from Macklin Biochemical Co.,Ltd., and 9, 10-DHA was purchased from Tokyo Chemical Industry. All reagents were used without any further treatment. Distilled water was made in the lab. The corresponding hydrogen type zeolite was obtained by NH4 + ion-exchange of NaY and then calcinated at 500 C for 6 h.

The chemical materials used in this work were tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS, 98%), aluminum isopropoxide (C9H21O3Al, 98%), sodium hydroxide (NaOH, 99%), tetrapropylammonium bromide (TPABr, 98%), sulphuric acid (H2SO4, 98%), ammonium chloride (NH4Cl, 99%), trimethylammonium Bromide (CTAB, 97%), chloroplatinic acid (H2PtCl6, 40 wt%), n-Pentane (C5H12, 99.99%). All the reagents were used as received without further purification. <header>Catalyst preparation<text>Na-ZSM-5 was synthesized based on the procedure reported by Yaripour et al. [32]. In a typical procedure, TPABr was dissolved in 13 ml deionized water in a beaker, and then 5 g TEOS was added to the solution and stirred for 60 min at room temperature (solution A). Solution B was prepared by dissolving 0.213 g aluminum isopropoxide in 13.5 ml of water. After 30 min of stirring, 0.208 g NaOH was added to the solution and stirred for another 30 min. Solution B was added dropwise to solution A. The molar composition of the prepared material was 1SiO2:0.04Al2O4:0.16Na:83H2O. The pH of the final solution was set to 10 by adding H2SO4 (2 M) during the stirring process. The solution was put into a 150 ml Teflon-lined autoclave at 175 C. After 72 h, the autoclave was quenched in cold water, and the obtained sample was filtered and washed three times with deionized water and dried in an oven at 110 C overnight. The obtained solid was calcined at 550 C (3 C/min) for five h to remove impurities. Desilication was done by introducing 1 g of Na-ZSM-5 to 20 ml NaOH solution (0.2 or 0.5 M) while stirring at 65 C for one h. After that, the suspension was filtered and washed three times with deionized water, and then the wet cake was dried at 110 C overnight. To synthesize MCM-41/ZSM-5 samples, 1 g of Na-ZSM-5 was dispersed in 10 ml NaOH (0.5 M) solution and stirred for 30 min at room temperature. Another solution containing X wt.% CTAB in 20 ml deionized water was prepared, and then the solution containing CTAB was added dropwise to the first solution, and the prepared solution was stirred for 60 min. The obtained solution was transferred into a stainless-steel Teflon-lined autoclave at 110 C. After 24 h, the autoclave was cooled down to room temperature, and H2SO4 solution (2 M) was added to the mixture to adjust the desired pH value. The autoclave was sealed again and remained in the oven for another 24 h at 110 C. The solid products were filtered, washed three times, and dried overnight at 110 C. To remove organic templates, the samples were calcined in an air atmosphere for five h at 550 C to remove organic templates. Na-type samples were transformed to H-form by ion exchange with 1 mol/L NH4Cl solution at 80 C for two h. The ion-exchanged samples were filtered and washed with deionized water to remove chloride ions. This procedure was repeated two times, and the samples were dried at 110 C overnight. Platinum was loaded on the as-dried samples via impregnation method using H2PtCl6 solution to achieve 0.3 wt% Pt. The impregnated samples were dried at 110 C and calcined at 450 C for 4 h (3 C/min). All the samples synthesized in this work are listed in the following table - <R><C>Sample<C>Post-treatment<C>NaOH molarity<C>CTAB wt.%<C>pH<C>Si/Al[NOTE] Si/Al by XRF analysis.<C>Pt loading %[NOTE] Pt loading of prepared samples using ICP-OES analysis.<R><C>ZS<C>Parent ZSM-5<C>–<C>–<C>–<C>24.9<C>0.292<R><C>DZ0.2<C>Desilication<C>0.2<C>–<C>–<C>23.2<C>0.313<R><C>DZ0.5<C>Desilication<C>0.5<C>–<C>–<C>22.1<C>0.296<R><C>ZM1<C>Des-reassembly<C>0.5<C>5<C>8.5<C>25.3<C>0.301<R><C>ZM2<C>Des-reassembly<C>0.5<C>10<C>8.5<C>25.8<C>0.293<R><C>ZM3<C>Des-reassembly<C>0.5<C>15<C>8.5<C>26.9<C>0.286<R><C>ZM4<C>Des-reassembly<C>0.5<C>10<C>10<C>23.1<C>0.281<R><C>ZM5<C>Des-reassembly<C>0.5<C>10<C>13<C>21.3<C>0.271<Cap>Synthesis conditions of post-treatment methods and the Si/Al ratio and Pt loading of prepared samples.</Cap> .

text: <header>Preparation of samples<text>ZSM-48 zeolite was synthesized by seed-assistance route according to our previous work [36,37]. The detailed synthesis procedure was displayed in the Supplementary Material . Typically, the initial gel with the composition of 1.2 HMBr2: 60 SiO2: 0.75 Al2O3: 3.95 Na2O: 1200 H2O: 0.20 wt% crystal seed was hydrothermally crystallized for 24 h at 180 C. After filtration and calcination, the pristine zeolite ZSM-48 was subjected to consecutively multi-step leaching post-treatment procedures, including alkaline-acid, acid-alkaline-acid, H2O steaming-alkaline-acid, and NH4F-alkaline-acid, denoted as ZSM-48(A), ZSM-48(B), ZSM-48(H), and ZSM-48(F), respectively. The description scheme of post-treatment leaching procedures was exhibited in Fig. 1 . For Series I, ZSM-48 was firstly suffered from alkaline-treatment for desilication in 0.2 M NaOH solution at 80 C for 2 h (1 g/30 ml). After drying at 80 C for 8 h and sequential dealumination was performed in 0.1 M HNO3 at 60 C for 0.5 h (1 g/30 ml). For acid-alkaline-acid, steaming-alkaline-acid, and fluorination-alkaline-acid leaching routes, the pristine ZSM-48 was firstly subjected to (1) dealumination in 1 M HNO3 at 80 C for 1 h (1 g/30 ml); (2) H2O steaming treatment at 550 C for 2 h with water vapor WHSV of 2.4 h-1; (3) fluorination in 0.3 M NH4F solution at 30 C for 10 h (1 g/10 ml), respectively. Then the subsequent mild desilication in 0.2 M NaOH solution at 80 C for 0.5 h and mild dealumination in 0.1 M HNO3 solution at 60 C for 0.5 h was performed successively (1 g/30 ml). The obtained powder was filtrated, washed, dried, and calcined at 550 C for 5 h, prior to three sequential ammonium exchanges in 0.5 M NH4NO3 at 80 C (1 g/30 ml). After calcination at 550 C for 5 h, H-form zeolites was impregnated in H2PtCl6 solution for 0.5 wt% Pt metal loading, and then Pt-impregnated catalysts was calcined at 400 C for 3 h under a mixed flow (O2/Ar, 40/40 ml/min) with a heating rate of 2 C/min. Pt-supported catalysts were activated at 400 C for 3 h under pure H2 flow (40 ml/min) with a heating rate of 2 C/min before reaction.

The reagents used were: colloidal silica (40%, Sigma-Aldrich), sodium aluminate (54.5% Al2O3 and 43.3% Na2O, Sigma-Aldrich), ethylenediamine – EDA (99%, Sigma-Aldrich), sodium hydroxide (98%, Sigma-Aldrich), Luviquat FC 550 (40%, Sigma-Aldrich), NH4FER zeolite (CP914C, Zeolyst), ammonium nitrate (99%, Sigma-Aldrich), ultra-high molecular weight polyethylene – UHMWPE (Sigma-Aldrich, average Mw: 3,000,000–6,000,00), and distilled water. <header>Synthesis of the ferrierite zeolites<text>The ferrierite zeolite was synthesized by the VPT method, whose composition and methodology for preparing the synthesis gel were adapted from Cheng et al. [19]. The reagents were mixed in stoichiometric proportions to obtain a gel with the following molar composition: 3 Na2O: 1 Al2O3: 20 SiO2: 400 H2O: Y NH4FER: X Luviquat, where Y = 10%, and X = 20%, 40%, or 60% relative to the total mass of silica. The reaction mixture was prepared through the following steps: (i) dissolution of sodium aluminate in one-third of the total water required for the synthesis (Solution I), (ii) dilution of sodium hydroxide in one-third of the water (Solution II), (iii) mix Solution I and II, then add the colloidal silica under stirring at 200 rpm at 50 C for 1 h (Solution III), (iv) gradually add the suspension of NH4FER seed crystals (previously dispersed in one-third of the water) in Solution III until complete homogenization, (v) add the Luviquat polymer to the remaining solution, maintaining the same agitation conditions, temperature, and time as in step (iii). The obtained synthesis gel was subsequently dried in an oven at 80 C for 12 h and then crushed in a stainless-steel analytical knife mill. The dried and ground gel was carefully placed in an open Teflon vessel attached to a support (Fig. 1 (a)). This container was then inserted into a hermetically sealed Teflon vessel, which contained at the bottom 2 g of an EDA solution in distilled water mixed at a ratio of 1:2 (v/v) for every 1 g of dry gel, as illustrated in Fig. 1(b). The set was transferred to a stainless-steel autoclave (Fig. 1(c)) and heated in an oven at 160 C for 24 h. A polymer-free sample was synthesized under the same conditions to serve as a reference (denoted as an FP sample). After the synthesis period, the resulting solid was recovered by vacuum filtration, washed with distilled water until reaching approximately neutral pH, and then dried in an oven at 80 C for 12 h. Subsequently, the samples were calcined from room temperature to 550 C for 6 h, under the heating rate of 2 C·min-1 and airflow of 100 mL min-1. The acidic FER zeolites were obtained by ion exchange using a 0.10 M ammonium nitrate solution, with a proportion of 1 g of sample for each 50 mL of solution, under stirring at 200 rpm for 2 h at 65 C. This process was repeated three times to ensure a high degree of ionic exchange, replacing Na + cations with NH4+ cations. After the exchange, the samples were recovered by filtration, washed, dried, and calcined under the previously described conditions (designated as FL20, FL40, and FL60 samples).<header>Post-synthesis treatment<text>The alkaline treatment of the calcined zeolites was carried out in a 300 mL Parr 4560 reactor using a solution of 0.20 M sodium hydroxide under stirring at 200 rpm at 80 C for 6 h. For all experiments, a proportion of 3.3 g of zeolite was used per 100 mL of alkaline solution [31]. After the treatment period, the solid was recovered by centrifugation, washed until reaching an approximately neutral pH, and then dried in an oven at 80 C for 12 h. The material obtained was subjected to ion exchange and calcined again under the same conditions described above (denoted as FPD, FL20D, FL40D, and FL60D samples).
