text: <header>Synthesis and characterization of the hierarchical HZSM-5 by alkali treatment<text>The HZSM-5 (Si/Al ratio = 25) was obtained from Nankai University Catalyst Co., Ltd. in China. The hierarchical HZSM-5 was prepared by the desilication approach using NaOH solution according to the previous literature reports [42,43]. First, calcination of the HZSM-5 was performed in muffle furnace at 550 C for 6 h to obtain the protonic form of ZSM-5. Then, the calcined zeolite was treated by the NaOH solutions with varying concentrations of 0.1, 0.3, 0.5, and 0.7 M. In this step, 5 g of calcined ZSM-5 was added into 150 mL NaOH solution, and stirred at 65 C for 30 min. After that, the desilication treated ZSM-5 was washed by deionized water to neutral. At last, the desilication treated ZSM-5 was ion exchanged in aqueous 1.0 M NH4NO3 solution at 50 C for 2 h, and then dried and calcined again to obtain acidic H-form of hierarchical HZSM-5. The HZSM-5 pretreated by varying concentrations of NaOH solution was named as Z-0.1 M, Z-0.3 M, Z-0.5 M, and Z-0.7 M, respectively. The textural properties, acidity, and morphology of the raw and pretreated HZSM-5 was tested by gas sorption analyzer, NH3-TPD, and SEM/TEM. Detailed experimental process of these four analytical instruments could be observed in our previous publications [9,10].

Tetraethoxysilane (TEOS, 99%, Aladdin), tetrapropyl ammonium hydroxide (TPAOH, 25 wt%, Innochem), tetraammineplatinum nitrate (Pt(NH3)4(NO3)2, 99%, Alfa Aesar), aluminum nitrate nonahydrate (Al(NO3)3·9H2O, 99%, ACROS), ammonia water (NH3·H2O, 25–28%, Aladdin), phenanthrene (97%, TCI) and decalin (99%, Macklin) were used as obtained. Commercial ZSM-5 (CZ) zeolite was received from Nankai University Catalyst Plant. A Milli-Q water (18.2 MΩ·cm) was employed in all the experiments. <header>Catalysts synthesis<text>Hollow silicalite-1 (HS) and hollow ZSM-5 (HZ) zeolites were prepared by utilizing a post alkali treatment method [39,40]. Usually, 22.5 g of TEOS, 34.8 g of TPAOH and 49.0 g of H2O were blended in a flask and then stirred at 35 C overnight. Next, the mixture with a molar composition of 1 SiO2: 0.4 TPAOH: 35 H2O: 4 EtOH was transferred to a 150 mL of Teflon-lined steel autoclave and held at 170 C in a stove for 72 h. Subsequently, the product was collected by centrifugation, washed with H2O, dried at 120 C overnight, and roasted at 550 C for 8 h in a muffle. The sample obtained was marked as S-1. For the synthesis of HZ, 4.5 g of S-1 and 1.4 g of Al(NO3)3·9H2O were dispersed in a 90 mL of TPAOH solution (0.5 M), and heated to 170 C for 24 h. After cooled to room temperature, the sample was isolated by centrifuge, washed with H2O, dried at 120 C overnight, and calcined at 550 C for 8 h in a muffle. The ultimate product was denoted as HZ zeolite. In addition, to emphasize the effect of acidity in HZ zeolite for deep hydrogenation of aromatics, the HS was also prepared by the same procedure of HZ with no addition of the Al source. Highly dispersed platinum clusters anchored on various zeolites were fabricated by means of the strong electrostatic adsorption (SEA) strategy [36]. In a typical run, the desired amount of Pt(NH3)4(NO3)2 was dissolved in 200 mL of water, then the pH was adjusted to 11.5 with NH3·H2O solution. And the zeolite support was introduced under agitating intensely. Meanwhile, the amount of added zeolite was restricted to furnish a surface loading of 5000 m2/L and the metal loading of Pt was limited to 1.0 wt%. After stirred for 2 h, the solid powders were collected by centrifugalization, dried at 80 C overnight under vacuum conditions, and calcined at 450 C for 4 h with a heating rate of 1.0 C·min-1 in static air. The resulting products were labeled as Pt/HS-SEA, Pt/HZ-SEA and Pt/CZ-SEA, respectively. For comparison, wetness impregnation (WI) method was also utilized to prepare Pt catalysts. The zeolite was immersed in a aqueous solution of Pt(NH3)4(NO3)2. Subsequently, the superfluous solvent was evaporated at 60 C in water bath. Then, the sample was further dried in an oven overnight, followed by calcination at 450 C for 4 h. Finally, the obtained catalysts were denoted as Pt/CZ-WI and Pt/HZ-WI, respectively.

<header>Synthesis<text>The ZSM-22 zeolites were hydrothermally synthesized following a previously reported method using 1,6-diaminohexane (DAH, Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., ltd.) as the organic structure directing agent (OSDA) [29]. Briefly, the precursor solution with a molar composition of Al2O3: 80SiO2: 6K2O: 17.5DAH:2025 H2O was stirred at room temperature for 2 h. Then, the mixture was transferred to a Teflon-lined stainless-steel reactor and crystallized at 160 C for 48 h under autogenous pressure. Finally, the solid product was filtered, dried and calcined in air conditions at 560 C for 8 h. Calcined sample (denoted as KZ22) was repeatedly exchanged with the aqueous solution of NH4Cl at 80 C (3 × 3 h, 50 mL of a solution per 1 g of zeolite), washed with deionized water, dried at 120 C for 12 h. The ion-exchanged sample was labeled as NZ22. Then, the protonated zeolite ZSM-22 (Z22) was derived by calcining zeolite NZ22 as obtained at 450 C for 4 h without any further post-treatments. The controllable desilication treatment was carried out by introducing the NZ22 sample in the aqueous solution consisting cetyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB, Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., ltd.) and NaOH solution of different concentrations at 80 C for 10 h. After this procedure, the resulting solid was washed using deionized water until pH neutral and dried at 60 C for 24 h. Then, the samples were treated in an aqueous solution of 0.1 HCl at 80 C for 2 h. The Na ions were entirely removed from the solid products by exchanging with 0.5 M NH4Cl for 3 times. Finally, the samples were dried overnight and calcined in a furnace at 550 C for 4 h. The protonic samples were denoted as CZ22-015, CZ22-03, and CZ22-045, according to the NaOH concentrations (0.15 M, 0.3 M, and 0.45 M) in the desilication solution. For comparison, the NZ-22 sample was treated in the NaOH aqueous solution (0.3 M) at 80 C for 2 h without the addition of CTAB. The post-treatments consisting of the HCl wash, NH4Cl exchange, dryness and calcination followed the procedures of CZ22-x samples. The resulting solid product was labeled as DZ22-03.

text: <header>Catalysts preparation and characterization<text>Three PtPd catalysts supported on Y zeolite have been used. The zeolite (ultrastable CBV712) has been supplied by Zeolyst International in the ammonium form with a SiO2/Al2O3 ratio of 12. The first catalyst (Cat-A) has been prepared using the zeolite without being submitted to any desilication treatment. The second one (Cat-B), has been prepared after submitting the zeolite to a desilication treatment (detailed below), whereas the third one (Cat-C) has been prepared after submitting twice the zeolite to the desilication treatment. The alkaline treatment method followed for zeolite desilication has consisted on [31]: i) suspension of 10 g in 300 mL of 0.1 M aqueous NaOH solution and stirring for 15 min at room temperature; ii) neutralization of the suspension with an equivalent amount of 1.0 M HCl solution to quench the desilication treatment. No longer contact times are required since using an aqueous NaOH solution, most of the mesoporosity is developed in the first 15 min [41,42]; iii) the desilicated zeolite was filtered and washed with deionized water; iv) the zeolite was subjected to two subsequent ion exchange cycles of 24 h with a 0.50 M aqueous solution of NH4Cl at room temperature (zeolite/solution ratio of 1 g/5 mL), in order to ensure that the Na introduced during the leaching stage is totally removed. Lastly, v) the zeolite was filtered, washed with deionized water, dried in an oven at 110 C for 16 h, and calcined in a muffle at 550 C, using a heating ramp of 12 C min-1, and maintaining that temperature for 4 h. In all the cases, the incorporation of the metals (1 wt% of Pt and 0.5 wt% of Pd) has been carried out following the procedure described by Gutiérrez et al. [43]. The behavior of PtPd as a metal function to activate hydrogenation reactions is well established [44]. This bimetallic function offers advantages over each of the individual metals in terms of stability and higher conversion, due to its lower S retention. Moreover, the PtPd catalyst supported on HY zeolite is very stable and has an outstanding capacity for obtaining naphtha and medium distillates [43–45]. The catalysts have been extensively characterized in order to correlate their physicochemical properties with their catalytic behavior. In this way, the textural properties have been determined from the N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms. The crystalline structure of the supports has been analyzed by X-ray diffraction. The acidic properties have been measured by temperature-programmed desorption/cracking of tert-butylamine and by pyridine FTIR analysis. The composition of the catalysts and the metal content have been measured by wavelength dispersion X-ray fluorescence spectrometry and inductively coupled plasma with atomic emission spectroscopy, respectively. In addition, some TEM images have been acquired for characterizing in a higher extent the structure of the catalyst and for observing the metal dispersion. Finally, the coke deposited on the catalysts has been measured by temperature-programmed oxidation. The equipment used for each analysis, as well as the procedures followed are available in the Supplementary Material.

text: <header>Primary synthesis of Nanosized zeolite Beta<text>The synthesis of zeolite beta was conducted using the methodology outlined in the pertinent literature [16]. In this study, the silica source used was fumed silica (Degussa, Aerosil 200), whereas the aluminum source employed was aluminum powder. Additionally, tetraethylammonium hydroxide (TEAOH) (Aldrich, 35% aqueous solution) was utilized as the template agent. The precursor gel was composed of oxides with the following molar ratio: 30TEAOH: 50SiO2:Al2O3:750H2O. Aluminum metal was dissolved in a TEAOH-containing aqueous solution, resulting in the formation of a transparent solution. Subsequently, this solution was introduced into a slurry composed of fumed silica and another portion of the TEAOH-containing aqueous solution. The aluminosilicate fluid gel that was created was agitated in a beaker at room temperature for 4 h. Following, it was placed into a Teflon-lined autoclave. The process of crystallization was conducted at a temperature of 140 C in a rotational state at a speed of 60 rpm for 3 days. The autoclave was subjected to quenching to stop the crystallization reaction. The separation of the finished product from the liquid was achieved by using a centrifuge operating at a speed of 16,000 rpm. Subsequently, the separated product underwent a washing process using deionized water until the pH level reached a value lower than 9.0. Finally, the product was subjected to a drying procedure in an oven at a temperature of 110 C. The resultant solid sample was named as NB-NC (nano-beta non-calcinated) in which the TEAOH template was not burned off.<header>Hierarchical nanosized beta synthesis<text>Mesoporous nanosized beta zeolites were synthesized by employing two main strategies consisting of hydrothermal treatment (steaming) and base treatment methods for non-calcined (NB-NC) and calcined (NB-C) nanosized beta zeolites. In the hydrothermal treatment method, the NB-NC (with TEAOH in the zeolite pores) or its calcinated counterpart (NB-C) samples were steamed using an autoclave reactor at temperature of 550 C for one hour and the pressure was maintained at 0.1 MPa throughout the treatment time by adjusting the pressure relief valve. Subsequently, the recovered steamed solids were calcined at 600 C for 4 h to remove the organic agents and the resultant products were named as NB-NC-HT-C and NB-C-HT-C respectively. In the base treatment method, two kind of experiments were carried out as follow: 1) a mixture of 0.5 M ammonia and hexadecyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB) was mixed with NB-C or NB-NC, 2) only 0.5 M ammonia was mixed with NB-C or NB-NC. The two experiments were conducted by using PTFE lined 140 ml autoclave, and heated in the oven at 150 C for 10 h. Then, the autoclave was quenched and the final solid product was separated from the liquid using a 12,000 rpm centrifugation. The recovered solid was washed several times with distilled water, dried at 110 C, and subsequently, calcined at 600 C for 4 h to remove the organic agents. The resultant samples were named as NB-NC-BT and NB-NC-BT-wCTAB respectively. The synthesis conditions and samples names are summarized in Fig. 1 and the following table - <R><C>ParentBeta<C>NB-NCNanosized (non-calcined)<C>NB-NCNanosized (non-calcined)<C>NB-CNanosized (calcined)<C>NB-CNanosized (calcined)<R><C>[EMPTY]<C>Steam treated<C>Base treated<C>Steam treated<C>Base treated<R><C>ModifiedSamples<C>NB-NC-HT<C>NB-NC-BT<C>NB-C-HT<C>NB-C-BT<R><C>[EMPTY]<C>NB-NC-HT-C<C>NB-NC-BT-wCTAB<C>NB-C-HT-C<C>NB-C-BT-wCTAB<Cap>Summary of samples and synthesis conditions.</Cap> . The main parameters for base treatment were as follow: ammonia to zeolite ratio was 16.7 (ml/g), and CTAB to zeolite weight ratio was 0.3 (g/g).<header>Hydrocracking catalyst synthesis<text>In order to evaluate the catalytic efficiency of mesoporous nanosized beta zeolites in the process of crude oil direct hydrocracking, a set of six hydrocracking catalysts was prepared by using the modified nanosized beta zeolites. The hydrocracking catalysts were formulated as a combination including hierarchical beta zeolites, large-pore alumina (sasol PURALOX TH100/150, with a specific surface area of 201.6 m2/g and a pore volume of 0.96 ml/g), MoO3, nickel nitrate hexahydrate, and binder (partially acid-peptized alumina, sasol, CATAPAL B). These were meticulously blended to create a homogenous mixture suitable for extrusion. The combination underwent extrusion to produce extrudate with a cylindrical shape. Subsequently, it was subjected to drying at a temperature of 110 C for the duration of one night. Finally, the extrudate was calcined in an air environment at a temperature of 500 C for 4 h. The composition of all catalysts is the same, consisting of MoO3 (15 wt%), NiO (5 wt%), zeolite (50 wt%), and alumina (30 wt%). The formulated hydrocracking catalysts with the following zeolites: NB-C, NB-NC, NB-C-BT, NB-NC-HT, NB-NC-BT, and NB-NC-BT-wCTAB were designated as HC-1, HC-2, HC-3, HC-4, HC-5 and HC-6, respectively.

text: <header>Synthesis and characterization of Ga modified hierarchical HZSM-5<text>The HZSM-5 (Si/Al ratio = 25) was obtained from Nankai University Catalyst Co., ltd. in China. The hierarchical HZSM-5 was obtained by the alkali desilication pretreatment. First of all, the calcined HZSM-5 (550 C for 5 h) was treated by NaOH solution with 0.3 mol/l at 80 C for 30 min. Because the NaOH concentration of 0.3 mol/l has been proved to obtain maximum aromatics’ yield during biomass CFP according to the previous works [29,36]. Then, the hierarchical HZSM-5 was obtained after the following steps of deionized water washing, ion exchanged in 1.0 mol/l NH4NO3 solution, and calcination. After that, the Ga precursor solution was mixed with the hierarchical HZSM-5 where the Ga metal content was fixed at 2 wt%. The Ga/hierarchical-HZSM-5 was obtained after the following steps of water evaporation, drying, and calcination. The parent, alkali treated, and metal modification catalysts were abbreviated as Parent-H, Hie-H, and Ga/Hie-H. The textural properties, acidity, and morphology of catalysts were tested by BET, NH3-TPD, SEM/TEM, respectively. Detailed experimental process of these four analytical instruments could be observed in our previous publications [3,4].

Aluminum isopropoxide (C9H21AlO3) and ethyl acetate (C4H8O2) were purchased from Shanghai Aladdin CO, ltd, Chnia. NCC was purchased from Shanghai Tonghua. TEOS was purchased from Thermo Fisher Scientific, USA. Tetrapropylammonium hydroxide (TPAOH, 40.0 wt%) was purchased from Shanghai Titan. LDPE was purchased from Sigma-Aldrich, USA. <header>Synthesis of HZZ by employing NCC as the mesoporous template<text>The HZZ catalyst was synthesized by conventional hydrothermal method with NCC template. The effect of NCC addition amounts (only ZSM-5, 2.5 %, 5 %, 10 % and 20 %) and Si/Al ratios (SARs, only ZSM-5, 80, 100 and 150) on the properties of HZZ were investigated. Specially, an appropriate amount of C9H21AlO3 was weighed and added to deionized water. Then a certain amount of TPAOH was added to the C9H21AlO3 solution and stirred for 2 h at room temperature until the solution was clear and transparent. Next, a certain amount of TEOS was added to the mixtures and stirring the solution for 2 h until the solution was clear and transparent again, and kept at 80 C for 12 h to form the crystal. Then the NCC was added into it after sonicating for 30 min to make it evenly dispersed. The resulted homogeneous white emulsion was heated at 180 C for 24 h in an autoclave, then centrifuged at 10,000 rpm for 10 min after cooling to room temperature. The solid was collected and washed 3 times repeatedly, then dried at 80 C for 12 h. The resulting white solid was calcined at 550 C for 6 h in a muffle furnace, then the HZZ was obtained, which was noted as X% NCC-ZSM-5 (Y), where X% is the mass ratio of NCC to SiO2 and Y is the SAR.

text: <header>Catalysts preparation<text>HZSM-5 zeolites used to prepare the bifunctional catalysts were purchased from the catalyst plant of Nankai University. The zeolites were calcined in muffle furnace in 550 C for 5 h to remove the template, water and other adsorption impurities. Bifunctional catalysts with Ni loading of 5 % were prepared by equal volume impregnation method using HZSM-5 zeolites with different silica-aluminum ratios. The loading is the mass ratio of the metal element to the HZSM-5, and the prepared catalysts were expressed as 5Ni/Z-X (5 denotes 5 % loading of metal Ni on the catalyst; X = 18, 25, 50, 80, 100, representing the silica-alumina ratios of the zeolites). Loading of metals on HZSM-5 support was conducted by equal volume impregnating HZSM-5 in Ni(CH₃COO)₂·4H₂O solution at room temperature (20 C) for 24 h. The prepared catalysts were dried in air at 50 C and 100 C for 5 h in a drying oven. Then catalysts were calcined in air at 500 C for 4 h in a furnace. HZSM-5 zeolites with a Silica-alumina ratio of 25 was selected and loaded with different Ni contents, and the catalysts were noted as xNi/Z-25 (x = 1, 3, 5, 7, and 9, denoting the loading of the Ni as x%), respectively.

<header>Preparation of catalysts<text>ZSM-5 was prepared in the following procedure: 2.7 g of NaOH was mixed with 25 ml of tetrapropylammonium hydroxide (TPAOH, 25%). Then a certain amount of water, aluminium isopropoxide and tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS) were added to the solution. Final molar ratio of Al2O3: SiO2: TPAOH: Na2O: H2O is 1:50:10:7.11:2500. The mixture was agitated for 2 h at room temperature and was heated at 120 C for 72 h in hydrothermal vessel. The suspension was centrifugated and then dried at 60 C for 12 h. The solid was calcined at 550 C for 5 h. Ion exchange was done using 1 M solution of NH4NO3 at 80 C for 4 h by two same processes·NH3-ZSM-5 was calcined at 450 C for 3 h to obtain H-ZSM-5. Mesoporous HZSM-5 was prepared by NaOH treatment. The process was carried out using 0.1 mol/L NaOH solutions at 70 C for 30 min. After treatment, mesoporous ZSM-5 was obtained by filtration, drying, and calcination at 300 C for 5 h. SiO2 modified mesoporous ZSM-5 was done using chemical liquid deposition method. 10 g of the zeolite was suspended in 100 ml hexane and heated with stirring under reflux conditions. 0.6 ml TEOS was added into the mixture. The silylation was carried out for 1 h. Then hexane was volatilized by evacuation. The mixture was dried at 100 C for 2 h and calcined at 500 C for 4 h. The process was performed repeatedly for three times. In this study, mesoporous ZSM-5 was named as MZ5, SiO2 modification mesoporous ZSM-5 was named as SiMZ5.

text: <header>Synthesis of EMT zeolite<text>The synthesis of EMT zeolite was adapted from a method proposed in the literature [3]. The reagents used as sources of silicon and aluminum were silica Ludox 30 wt% (Sigma-Aldrich) and sodium aluminate (aluminate (AlO2 1-), sodium (1:1) – Fisher), 1,4,7,10,13,16-hexaoxacyclooctadecane (18-crown-6 ≥ 99.0 % Sigma-Aldrich) and sodium hydroxide (Sigma-Aldrich). The stoichiometric molar ratio of the synthesis gel was as follows: 0.044 NaAlO2: 0.64 SiO2: 0.017 18-crown-6: 1.17 H2O. The procedure for the synthesis gel preparation involves, under constant stirring, the dissolution of the sodium hydroxide in milli-Q water and the subsequent addition of sodium aluminate (stirring for 15 min), the 18-crown-6 (stirring for 1 h) and 30 wt% Ludox silica (stirring for 1 h). All these steps were performed at room temperature. The synthesis gel was placed in Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave reactors, left for 24 h at room temperature and subsequently subjected to crystallization under autogenous pressure and static conditions at 110 C for 13 d. After crystallization, the so obtained solid was recovered by filtration, washed thoroughly with distilled water (until the pH reached neutral value), and dried at 100 C for 12 h. Finally, the material was calcined at 550 C for 6 h with a heating ratio of 1 C·min-1 and coded as EMT.<header>Post-synthesis method to produce hierarchical EMT zeolite<text>The post-synthesis treatment was performed using 1 g of calcined EMT zeolite in a solution containing 1.3 g of ammonium fluoride (NH4F, Sigma-Aldrich, 98 %) and 6 g of H2O. In a second series of experiments, 0.7 g of cetyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB, Aldrich, 99 %) was also added to the solution. The mixture was subjected to ultrasound at temperatures of 25 and 65 C for times of 30 min, 1 h, and 4 h with frequency 40 KHz. Then, it was vacuum filtered, the recovered solid being washed carefully with distilled water until the pH reached a neutral value, dried in an oven at 100 C for 12 h, and calcined at 550 C for 6 h. Samples were coded as E-D x y +C, where D indicates that the catalyst has the demetallization treatment, x and y represent time and temperature (if not carried out at room temperature) of this treatment, respectively, whereas +C indicates that the sample has been prepared in the presence of CTAB. To obtain the EMT zeolite in its protonic form, 1 g of the calcined zeolite was subjected to an ion exchange procedure using 100 mL of a 1 mol.L-1 ammonium chloride (NH4Cl) solution at 80 C for 2 h, under agitation in a reflux system. Subsequently, the solid was vacuum filtered, washed with approximately 1 L of distilled water at 80 C to remove unexchanged ammonium ions (NH4 +) and chloride ions (Cl-) and then oven dried at 100 C. To ensure an efficient ion exchange process, this procedure was repeated 3 times. Then, the zeolite was calcined at 400 C with a heating rate of 10 C.min-1 for 3 h. The resulting material was named as H-EMT.

text: Bamboo purchased from Zhejiang Province was used as biomass feedstock. Before the experiment, it was crushed and sieved to obtain powder with a particle size of about 100 mesh and then dried at 110 C for 48 h. The proximate analysis of the air-dried basis bamboo was 71.42 wt.% volatile, 7.36 wt.% moisture, 2.94 wt.% ash and 18.28 wt.% fixed carbon, and the ultimate analysis of the daf (dry and ash free) basis bamboo was 51.51 wt.% carbon, 6.12 wt.% hydrogen, 42.05 wt.% oxygen, 0.21 wt.% nitrogen and 0.11 wt.% sulfur. <header>Chemical liquid deposition of HZSM-5 catalysts<text>10 g HZSM-5 was dissolved into 100 mL pure ethyl alcohol in a conical flask; a corresponding amount of TBT modifier was then added to the slurry, and the mix was left in a water bath at 40 ℃ for 4 h. After reaction, the liquid was steamed in a rotary evaporation device, and the resultant specimen was placed in an oven to dry at 105 ℃ for 12 h, before being finally calcined at 550 ℃ for 4 h. The SiO2-modified samples were prepared in the same manner, except that the modifier and solvent were changed to TEOS and n-hexane, respectively. Catalysts with different deposition amounts and times were also prepared, and catalysts that contained x wt.% (x = 2, 4, 8, 12) TiO2/SiO2, with 4 h deposition time, were named “x% TiO2/SiO2-HZ”.
